title: What Happened to the "Common Good"?
course_desc: It is up front and center in our founding document.  It was discussed in Europe since the Enlightenment and in the United States for 200 years.  What happened in the last 30-40 years to "downgrade" the "Common Good"? We will read Robert Reich's book that holds both Republicans and Democrats accountable for the disregard of the "Common Good" along with the lack of attention to our basic Democratic Institutions that are not necessarily written in law, but are/were part of the culture.  Can we function as a democracy without some common ground?  Reich identifies a new cultural norm of "do whatever it takes....to win"...."to maximize profits"...."to rig the economy"  for personal benefit. Do you agree with Reich?  Do you agree with his recommendations for the solution?  Is the loss of the "Common Good" the reason for the loss of bipartisanship in Congress and civility in the political process?  Let us brain-storm some creative ways to re-engage for the "Common Good".  Is it all about "me" or is there still a "we"?
Books (for catalog) 1: Robert Reich|The Common Good|Alfred A. Knopf, New York|2018|
Readings catalog text: Readings: Robert Reich, The Common Good (Alfred A. Knopf, New York, 2018).
course_info_string: Estimated outside work is two hours per week. Class size is limited to 22.
other_req_materials: Handouts will be provided by the SGL.
other_readings:
Handouts will be provided by the SGL.   Review of Reich's  book by Michael Sandel from the NYT.

"The Art of Reframing Issues"

Readings from "Recommended Readings"  in Reich's book.

A Discussion Guide for the "Common Good", from the book.
sgl_bio_1: Margo N. Woods received her undergraduate, B.S., degree from Montclair State College, her M.S. from Cornell University and here D. Sc. from Harvard School of Public Health.  Her career was spent as Associate Professor  at Tufts School of Medicine in teaching and Research.  Areas of expertise include:  Relationship of diet and estrogen metabolism in breast cancer, role of n-3 fatty acid metabolism in Metabolic Disease and protein metabolism in HIV.
Additional Schedule Information: No
Colloquium Room: I can use the Colloquium Room if that is the only way to accommodate my class size and schedule.
special_req: None
further_info: My goal is to engage the class in problem solving strategies to provide information, implication, reflection and strategy on re-invigorating our commitment, as a community and country in the principles of the "Common Good".   Why is it desirable and essential.   How can we be simple spokespeople for this idea?

title: Listen to This! Classical Music for Non-Musicians
course_desc: This class is intended for <u>anyone</u> with a general interest in classical music who wants to learn more about it. Three goals will animate our time together: 1) we will listen to and discuss 1000 years of Western "art" music from monasteries and troubadours to music of our time, pausing as appropriate to review musical vocabulary; musical styles and forms; the persons (men <u>and</u> women) who wrote the works we will study; and the socio-cultural setting from which these musical geniuses and their works arose. 2) We will deepen our ability to really "listen to" music, not just "hear" it. 3) If things go as planned, we'll have fun doing it.
Books (for catalog) 1: Smith, Tim|The NPR...Guide to Classical Music|Perigree|2002|
Books (for catalog) 2: Powell, John|How Music Works|Little Brown|2010|
Readings catalog text: Readings: Smith, Tim, The NPR...Guide to Classical Music (Perigree, 2002); Powell, John, How Music Works (Little Brown, 2010).
course_info_string: Estimated outside work is three hours per week. Class size is limited to 25.
other_req_materials: Lots and lots of YouTube performance clips. Some very light weekly reading (the assigned NPR Guide is chiefly a reference book.
other_readings: 1. Much of the "homework" involves listening to youtube performance clips. I will offer  (after-class) a tutorial on youtube as needed, but ability to find and play youtube clips--or to learn to do so--is, let's say, required. 2. Some handouts (mostly words from songs) 3. Optional Reading: How Music Works, by John Powell (Little Brown). A very useful (and engaging book on musuc "basic:" melody, harmony, rhythm, etc)
sgl_bio_1: Clark Baxter published college-level music textbooks (for music majors and non-majors) for many years, including best-selling texts for classes in "music appreciation." He has sung most of the major choral works we will listen to and discuss in class, but will not do so in class unless provoked.
Additional Schedule Information: Morning or afternoon on any day is okay, but I prefer an afternoon slot.
Colloquium Room: I can use the Colloquium Room if that is the only way to accommodate my class size and schedule.
special_req: As per discussions with Tess, the purpose of repeating this class is to accommodate anyone who, quite unexpectedly tried to enroll last spring and was wait-listed. I strongly prefer to make this class available to any and every interested SGM this time: if demand exceeeds space in a "regular" room, my goals for the class can be easily met in the large "colloquium room (#205 I think?) The availability there of a piano will be a useful teaching tool.
further_info: I had at least one tech glitch in every week of the prior class. If the problem is an unprepared SGL I'll be gratefully receive a bit of coaching. If however any SGM is willing to sit near the podium (and maybe meet with me briefly before class every week) and play the assigned youtube clips while I lead the class discussions and beetle on about Mozart, that would be wonderful.

title: Six Patients Who Shaped End-of-Life Care: A 100 Year Retrospective
course_desc: Some of these patients, most of whom are women, you have probably heard of, including Karen Ann Quinlan and Nancy Beth Cruzan; others such as Mary Schloendorff and Helga Wanglie are known principally to medical ethicists. But all of them had their day in court (2 in the Supreme Court, the others in courts in California, Massachusetts, Minnesota, New Jersey, Texas) and their legal cases have arguably shaped end of life care in the United States today. We will read summaries of each of these cases and an article that puts them in context. Based on these pivotal cases, we will grapple with such critical concepts as informed consent, substituted judgment, futility, withholding versus withdrawing treatment, decision-making capacity, and patient autonomy.
Books (for catalog) 1: David Rothman|Strangers at the Bedside: A History of How Law and Bioethics Transformed Medical Decision Making|Basic Books|1992|
Readings catalog text: Readings: David Rothman, Strangers at the Bedside: A History of How Law and Bioethics Transformed Medical Decision Making (Basic Books, 1992).
course_info_string: Estimated outside work is four hours per week. Class size is limited to 12.
other_req_materials:
All the material will be provided on the course website. Each week, we will discuss one legal case (synopsis and analytical article provided) illustrating one or more ethical issues. The optional, supplementary reading will generally involve a second, related case. Week 1. Ethics and law in medicine; autonomy, self-determination, and informed consent Reading: David Rothman. Strangers at the Bedside. A History of How Law and Bioethics Transformed Medical Decision Making. NY: Basic Books, 1992 (selection) Case: Schloendorff v. Society of New York Hospital. NY Court of Appeals 105 N.E. 92, 211 N.Y. 125 Readings:
  1. Case summary
  2. Tom Beauchamp. "Informed Consent: its History, Meaning, and Present Challenges." Cambridge Quarterly of Healthcare Ethics 2011; 20:515-523.
Week 2. Withdrawing and withholding life-sustaining treatment Case: In re Quinlan. 70 N.J. 10, 355 A.2d 647 (NJ 1976) Readings:
  1. Case summary
  2. R Weir and L Gostin. “Deciding to Abate Life-Sustaining Treatment for Non-Autonomous Patients.” Journal of the American Medical Association 1990; 264: 1846-53.
Week 3. Futility; who decides for the incapacitated Case: In re the Conservatorship of Helga M. Wanglie. State of Minnesota District Court, Probate Court Division, County of Hennepin, Fourth Judicial District. Readings:
  1. Case summary
  2. R Truog, AS Brett, J. Frader. “The Problem with Futility.” New England Journal of Medicine 1992; 326: 1650-4.
  3. Ronald Cranford. Helga Wanglie's Ventilator. Hastings Center Report 1991; 21(4): 23-4.
Week 4.  Withdrawing vs withholding; is artificial nutrition medical treatment Case. Cruzan v Director, Missouri Department of Health, 497 U.S. 261 (1990) Readings:
  1. Case summary
  2. George Annas. “Nancy Cruzan and the Right to Die.” New England Journal of Medicine 1990; 323:670-3.
Week 5. Physician assisted suicide Case: Dianne Trumbull. Reading:
  1. Timothy Quill. “Death and Dignity: A case of individualized decision-making.” New England Journal of Medicine 1991; 324: 691-4.
Case: Vacco v. Quill, 521 U.S. 793 (1997). Reading:
  1. Case summary
  2. Lawrence Gostin, "Deciding Life and Death in the Courtroom: From Quinlan to Cruzan, Glucksberg, and Vacco--a Brief History and Analysis of Constitutional Protection of the Right to Die." JAMA 1997; 278(18): 1523-9.
Week 6. Brain death, religion, and politics. Case: Munoz v John Peter Smith Hospital, 96th District Court for Tarrant County, Texas. Readings:
  1. Case summary: Wade Goodwyn. “The Strange Case of Marlise Munoz and John Peter Smith Hospital.” Health News from NPR. January 28, 2014.
  2. Jeffrey Ecker. “Death in Pregnancy: an American Tragedy." New England Journal of Medicine 2014; 370:889-91
Wrap up
other_readings:
Video clips to be shown in class to highlight other perspectives: "Saying Goodbye" the Legacy of Karen Ann Quinlan. Interviews with her mother and priest. Terri Schiavo Documentary: The Case's Enduring Legacy. NY Times. Optional materials Week 1: Jay Katz. “Informed Consent: A Fairy Tale? Law’s Vision.” U of Pittsburgh Law Review  137 (1977) Week 2:  Case: Superintendent of Belchertown State School and others vs Joseph Saikewicz 373 Mass 728 (1977) Reading:
  1. Case summary
  2. William Curran. “The Saikewicz Decision.” New England Journal of Medicine 1978; 298: 499-502.
Week 3:  Case:  Lane v. Candura, 376 N.E. 2d 1232 (Mass. App. Ct. 1978). Reading:
  1. Case summary
  2. Paul Appelbaum. "Assessment of Patients' Competence to Consent to Treatment." New England Journal of Medicine 2007; 357:1834-40.
Week 4:  Case. Terri Schiavo. U.S. Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit - 403 F.3d 1289 (11th Cir. 2005) Reading:
  1. George Annas, 'Culture of Life:' Politics at the Bedside--the Case of Terri Schiavo.”  New England Journal of Medicine 2005.
Week 5:  Case. Washington v. Glucksberg 521 US 702(1977) Reading:
  1. Case summary
  2. Wendy Mariner. “Physician Assisted Suicide and the Supreme Court. Putting the Constitutional Claims to Rest.” American Journal of Public Health 1997; 87: 2058-62.
Week 6: Case. McMath et al v. State of California et al (2014) Reading:
  1. Case summary
  2. Christopher Burkle et al, “Why Brain Death is Considered Death and Why There Should be no Confusion.” Neurology 2014; 83:1464-9.
sgl_bio_1: Muriel R. Gillick is a physician who spent her career in geriatrics and palliative care. She has long been fascinated by ethical issues arising near the end of life and has written on this topic for a general audience.
small_room: The expectation is that this will be a discussion class, with the SGL serving to guide the discussion and provide a little background but no formal lectures.

title: Writing Your Family History
course_desc: Do you have photographs of your great-grandparents or notes about their grandparents? Perhaps you have a family tree or have collected information from a genealogical web site. How can you make sense of the facts you’ve acquired and preserve them for future generations? Whether you are beginning or continuing to write your family’s story, this course will provide guidance and group support. Members will spend most of each class discussing each other’s writing. We will also read a selection of other family history narratives for discussions of format, style, and the incorporation of contextual material. Whether your forebear was a farmer, a mother of twelve, a garment worker, or a prominent public figure, you will find that telling the story of his or her life is an instructive and moving experience. No writing experience is required, but you should know enough about one or more of your ancestors to begin writing.
course_info_string: Estimated outside work is two hours per week. Class size is limited to 12.
other_req_materials: Selections from published family history narratives will be provided on the course website.
other_readings:
We will handle member writing as Suzanne's memoir class did:  Members ready to present will bring paper copies of their work to class the week before it is presented.  All will read the pieces, make comments in the margin as desired, and return the copies to their author after the discussion.

Short selections from published narratives will be used to show the variety of styles used in family history narratives.  They will be taken from our personal libraries and from the extensive library of the New England Historic Genealogical Society.
sgl_bio_1: Susan Harris has been researching her family history for nearly twenty years and is working on a third book about her grandparents and their ancestry.  She has led four prior study groups including one on researching and writing a family history narrative.
sgl_bio_2: Lucretia Slaughter started researching her family history because her father did not know who his father was. She found out, wrote the story of her newfound grandfather, and has been writing about her ancestors ever since.  She has led three prior study groups.
small_room: For this course, a big table would be nice.  We will not use a screen much if at all.
special_req: I strongly prefer that this course be scheduled for the same day and time as the related course "Researching Your Family History"  which I am proposing for the first half.  If one of these two courses is deferred, the other one should be too.
further_info: This is the second of two sequential courses that I am proposing for the Spring Term, the first one being “Writing Your Family History.”  SGLs may take either or both courses (i.e. one is not a prerequisite for the other).  The two-course format arose after discussion with SGMs who took my 2018 course “Researching and Writing a Family History Narrative.”  The six-week format did not provide enough time to adequately discuss the unexpectedly high volume of written work produced by class members.  In discussion of this issue with them and others (I held a brown bag for that purpose) there was general agreement that separating the research and writing aspects into two different courses would solve this problem, hence the two proposals.  I’m planning to lead the research course alone because I am very experienced with the methods involved and prefer the efficiency of conducting that course alone.  I asked Lucretia Slaughter to co-lead the writing class with me because I think she would add a valuable second perspective as we explore members’ writing.  She is an excellent writer and editor, took my earlier course, and has written terrific narratives about some of her own family members.

title: Researching Your Family History
course_desc: Family history research goes beyond building family trees. Where did your ancestors live? What were their lives like? How were they influenced by the events of the day?  Each study group member will actively research at least one individual or couple during the course, and we will discuss research progress and problems as a group. We will cover project planning, data collection online and elsewhere, use of DNA testing in family history research, and other topics relevant to individual projects. For online research, members will use the free Family Search website or the subscription-based Ancestry website. Weekly exercises will involve data extraction from primary sources. The course text, Family Tree Factbook: Key Genealogy Tips and Stats for the Busy Researcher, will complement in-class exploration of data sources. No experience is required. SGMs should have good internet access and be able to access the course website.
Books (for catalog) 1: Diane Haddad|Family Tree Factbook: Key Genealogy Tips and Stats for the Busy Researcher|Family Tree Books|2018|
Readings catalog text: Readings: Diane Haddad, Family Tree Factbook: Key Genealogy Tips and Stats for the Busy Researcher (Family Tree Books, 2018).
course_info_string: Estimated outside work is two hours per week. Class size is limited to 12.
other_readings: Nothing not already mentioned in the CD.
sgl_bio_1: Susan Harris has been researching her family history for nearly twenty years and is working on a third book about her grandparents and their ancestry.  She has led four prior study groups including one on researching and writing a family history narrative.
small_room: I do need to demonstrate family history software on a screen but that worked fine in room 307 when I taught a version of this course last year.  Rooms 118 or G20 would probably be fine too.
special_req: I strongly prefer that this course be scheduled for the same day and time as a related course that I am proposing for the second half (Writing Your Family History).  This will allow interested SGMs to combine both courses for, effectively, a 12-week course.  See below for more on the two courses. Also, though I'm willing to defer this course, I don't want to run one course without the other, so am willing to defer only if both courses are deferred.
further_info: This is the first of two sequential courses that I am proposing for the Spring Term, the second one being “Writing Your Family History.”  SGMs may take either or both courses (i.e. one is not a prerequisite for the other).  The two-course format arose after discussion with SGMs who took my 2018 course “Researching and Writing a Family History Narrative.”  The six-week format did not provide enough time to adequately discuss the unexpectedly high volume of written work produced by class members.  In discussion of this issue with them and others (I held a brown bag for that purpose) there was general agreement that separating the research and writing aspects into two different courses would solve this problem, hence the two proposals.  I’m planning to lead the research course alone because I am very experienced with the methods involved and prefer the efficiency of leading solo.  I asked Lucretia Slaughter to co-lead the writing class with me because I think she would add a valuable second perspective as we explore members’ writing.  She is an excellent writer and editor, took my earlier course, and has written terrific narratives about some of her own family members.

title: Parlez-vous francais? Advanced Conversation
course_desc: We will read read La Peste and L’Etat de Siège by Albert Camus. Playwright, but most known for his novels and philosophical essays, he was awarded the Nobel prize for Literature in 1957. The readings and class discussions will be in French. Emphasis will be on discussion so that every participant will have opportunities to both hear and speak the language. We will also view video clips of relevant material, and a film based on the novel. If time permits, every member will give an oral expose on a topic of their choice. Active participation is expected.
Books (for catalog) 1: Albert Camus|La Peste|Folio Series, 42                                       French edition||
Books (for catalog) 2: Albert Camus|L'Etat de siege|Gallimard  French edition||
Readings catalog text: Readings: Albert Camus, La Peste (Folio Series, 42 French edition, ); Albert Camus, L'Etat de siege (Gallimard French edition, ).
course_info_string: Estimated outside work is two hours per week. Class size is limited to 12.
sgl_bio_1: Annie Geoghegan was born and raised in France. She taught at Duke University, Tufts, Harvard, MIT, and Boston University. She holds a License and a Maîtrise de Lettres from the University of Amiens, and an MA in International Development from the Fletcher School of Law and Diplomacy. She previously led 1 study group.
small_room: Because of  my increasing hearing handicap, I need a small room where I can face participants.  I will use the projector but any room where people sit around a table makes it  impossible for me to understand what is said, even with a microphone.

title: Jane Austen and the Economic Basis of Society
course_desc: Jane Austen wrote in an era when British society was being transformed by unstoppable industrialization, liberalized trade, and financial innovation.  While she witnessed Britain’s emergence as the first modern nation, she was inventing the first modern novel. Hers are stories of courtship within an identifiable world of money and property sketched with sometimes brutal realism. W.H. Auden famously recorded shock at seeing a middle-class spinster "reveal so frankly and with such sobriety / the economic basis of society." We will discuss four of Austen's novels in their economic contexts. Where did Darcy’s £10,000 pounds come from every year? Was Emma being foolish or financially savvy in preferring to remain unmarried? Was Mansfield Park built with money from the slave trade (and what was Sir Thomas Bertram doing in Antigua anyway)? How did the Napoleonic Wars make Captain Wentworth wealthy enough to propose a second time to Anne Elliot?
Books (for catalog) 1: Jane Austen|Pride and Prejudice|Oxford|2008|
Books (for catalog) 2: Jane Austen|Emma|Oxford|2008|
Readings catalog text: Readings: Jane Austen, Pride and Prejudice (Oxford, 2008); Jane Austen, Emma (Oxford, 2008); Jane Austen, Mansfield Park (Oxford, 2008); Jane Austen, Persuasion (Oxford, 2008).
course_info_string: Estimated outside work is four hours per week. Class size is limited to 20.
other_req_materials: Materials on history and economic background will be available from the web site.
other_readings: Additional details to follow.  Course is planned for September 2019.
sgl_bio_1: Jo Ann Citron wrote her Ph.D. dissertation on Jane Austen and hasn't read her seriously since, though she talks about her ceaseless in all the courses she leads.  Sometimes you just need to go back to your roots.
sgl_bio_2: Steven Harvey has co- led or led study groups on financial irregularities in Victorian novels, city government, and Silicon Valley. An investment manager and analyst by trade, he is by avocation a reader of novels and history.
Additional Schedule Information: Thursday is in there only because we had to put in a third choice, but there is a strong preference for Wednesday.
Colloquium Room: I cannot use the Colloquium Room.
special_req: If the course is limited to 20, there will be 22 people in the room counting the SGLs.  Citron's experience has been to mentally reserve a couple spots for wait list members or special circumstances.  Austen is perennially popular and we expect this course to be oversubscribed.  Whether we can take more than 20 members will depend on where it's held.
further_info: We're proposing this course for the Fall of 2019 as a full semester.  Steve and Jo Ann did something similar in the spring of 2018 with a Trollope novel that was based on a Ponzi scheme and the course was quite well received.  Several members expressed an interest in more of that kind of thing and so we're proposing this one.  We know which novels we'll read and we know what the economic readings will focus on.  We haven't put those readings together yet but we have plenty of time to do so.   This proposal is in the nature of a place holder for next fall, though the catalogue description won't change between now and then. Citron expects that some members of the committee might raise questions about the amount of reading.  To which she responds that most people are likely to have read at least 2 of the Austen novels; Persuasion and Pride and Prejudice are quite short; Austen is not heavy going; and people will have the summer to read ahead.  The Austen material is shorter and easier than was the Brontë material a couple years ago and members didn't have any trouble with the Brontë stuff.  Similarly, a few years ago, people in Purloined Letters read Daniel Deronda and The Portrait of a Lady in what turned out to be a 10 week semester when we lost 2 weeks to snow storms.  People who take novel courses are readers and Austen is hardly late James.

title: Lobbying and Pressure Groups
course_desc: Most Americans are not aware of the number of lobbyists (12,o0o0--14,000) who work in Washington, D.C. let alone the various statehouses throughout the U.S.  In this class we will explore what it is that lobbyists do for the legislative segment of our government, as well as other entities in our society. We will address such questions as: What does it take to become a lobbyist? Who in the government employs them? What skills do these entities bring to the party? Who pays them? How do they get paid? What type of people are attracted to this type of work? Why is there so much controversy associated with lobbyists? What are some of the recent cases that lobbyists have worked either for the government or groups out of it? These are just some of the questions we will address in this class. As you can imagine, discussing these issues will result in a lively class.
Books (for catalog) 1: Beth Leech|Lobbyists At Work|apress|2013|
Readings catalog text: Readings: Beth Leech, Lobbyists At Work (apress, 2013).
course_info_string: Estimated outside work is three hours per week. Class size is limited to 22.
other_req_materials: Other materials will be provided such as magazine articles,newspaper articles, and You videos.
other_readings: Any current events that appears in the major newspapers or magazines relative to this topic will be included as they appear.
sgl_bio_1: Richard Reidy was a former consultant in the political arena for the Mayor of Chicago, Mayor of Oakland, CA and CEOs of major corporations throughout the U.S. and Europe and will bring that experience to class.
Colloquium Room: I can use the Colloquium Room if that is the only way to accommodate my class size and schedule.
further_info: This is an active subject, and will continue to change as the course proceeds depending on the nature of the political happenings.  Thus, I will be adding and subtracting elements based upon the political climate.

title: Using "Keynote" in HILR Courses
course_desc: Easley Hamner has led 26 HILR courses since 2010 when he joined. All have relied on "Keynote," the Apple software, to create richly illustrated presentations. If you would like to enliven your HILR classes with images, you can learn much from this 6 week course. He will discuss his methods of finding illustrations, on the internet and in published sources, and how to manipulate them for effect. This will be a "hands-on" class, and members are invited to bring their laptops, with Keynote installed, to class. Even those using "PowerPoint" may learn pointers.
course_info_string: Estimated outside work is two hours per week. Class size is limited to 25.
other_req_materials: There are no books required. Links to internet articles will be referenced as required. You will find that having an iPad (or even an iPhone), will be highly desirable for your presentations.
sgl_bio_1: Easley Hamner is a retired architect, and used Microsoft's "PowerPoint" since the early 1990s for client presentations. He began using Apple's "Keynote" when he joined HILR for reasons he will discuss in the class.
Additional Schedule Information: I have no preference for day or time.  I selected Tuesday AM only because "This field is required."
Colloquium Room: I strongly prefer the Colloquium Room.
special_req: Having the large screen in the Colloquium Room is essential for this course.
further_info: Because many HILR members are away for the First Half, I am keenly interested in leading this course in both the First Half and in the Second Half.

title: Four Countries on the Edge: Turkey, Iran, Saudi Arabia, and Egypt
course_desc: These four countries surround the "hornets nest" of the Mid-East. Their histories and cultures, linked in our time by Islam, followed radically different trajectories to the present. Our course will begin with an introduction to Islam, then spend 3 or 4 weeks on each country, exploring and contrasting their history and culture, from the days of myth to the present. Our goal will be to discern the differences, and the similarities, of each so that we may better understand the issues they face in our modern world. As with all of my courses, the format will be richly illustrated lectures, with time for questions.
Books (for catalog) 1: William Cleveland and Martin Bunton|A History of the Modern Middle East|Westview Press|2016|6th
Books (for catalog) 2: Peter Mansfield|A History of the Middle East|Penguin Books|2013|4th
Readings catalog text: Readings: William Cleveland and Martin Bunton, A History of the Modern Middle East (Westview Press, 2016); Peter Mansfield, A History of the Middle East (Penguin Books, 2013).
course_info_string: Estimated outside work is two hours per week. Class size is limited to 25.
other_req_materials: Study Group Members are invited to read one or both of the texts.
other_readings: I will be using a host of additional books, together with earlier course materials, and images from the internet for my presentations.
sgl_bio_1: Easley Hamner, a retired architect and world traveler, has long been intrigued by the Middle East, and by Islam. He has led two earlier courses on the subject: The Greater Middle East - Spring '17, and The Islamic World - Spring '18. In addition, he has been an active participant of three of Sultan Zia's courses on the region.
Colloquium Room: I strongly prefer the Colloquium Room.

title: The Fairy Tale and Modern Culture: Old Wine in New Bottles
course_desc: Fairy tales are derived from oral traditions celebrating wonder. "Once upon a time there was a . . . someone who used impossible means to overcome terrible obstacles until finally there was a happily-ever-after." Shaped over countless centuries by storytellers from disparate societies, the narratives resonate long after childhood has ended. Improbable yet satisfying fairy tales are part of contemporary culture and have continuing impact on it. Why do they affect us? And how has modern culture affected the fairy tale? Discussions will consider origins of and modifications to a variety of classic wonder tales from the Brothers Grimm and other sources. Additionally, we will examine articles by commentators delving into the psychological content and sociological impact of the stories. Our studies will be balanced with examinations of contemporary wonder-inspired fiction and poetry by Angela Carter, Neil Gaiman, Linda Pastan, Sylvia Plath, Anne Sexton, and others.
Books (for catalog) 1: Maria Tatar, trans. and ed.|The Grimm Reader: The Classic Tales of the Brothers Grimm|W.W. Norton & Company|2010|
Books (for catalog) 2: Angela Carter|The Bloody Chamber and Other Stories|Penguin Books|1990|
Readings catalog text: Readings: Maria Tatar, trans. and ed., The Grimm Reader: The Classic Tales of the Brothers Grimm (W.W. Norton & Company, 2010); Angela Carter, The Bloody Chamber and Other Stories (Penguin Books, 1990).
course_info_string: Estimated outside work is two hours per week. Class size is limited to 20.
other_req_materials: Members will buy a course pack of selected readings. A list of additional suggested readings and links to podcasts will be on the course website. Some short film clips will be shown in class.
other_readings: Excerpts from the following books will be used in a course reader: Mirror, Mirror on the Wall: Women Writers Explore Their Favorite Fairy Tales, ed. Kate Bernheimer; The Uses of Enchantment by Bruno Bettleheim; The Witch Must Die: How Fairy Tales Shape Our Lives by Sheldon Cashdan; The Madwoman in the Attic by Sandra Gilbert and Susan Gubar; Once Upon a Time: On the Nature of Fairy Tales by Max Luthi; Transformations by Anne Sexton; From the Beast to the Blonde and Once Upon a Time by Marina Warner; When Dreams Came True: Classical Fairy Tales and Their Tradition by Jack Zipes.
sgl_bio_1: Judith Elstein was a high school literature teacher and a national teacher-trainer for the Folger Shakespeare Library. She is fascinated by the resilience and mutability of fairy tales.
Additional Schedule Information: Afternoons only.
Colloquium Room: I can use the Colloquium Room if that is the only way to accommodate my class size and schedule.
special_req: I prefer a room without a seminar table.

title: Lolita: Nabokov's Offensive Masterpiece
course_desc: Ever since its publication in the 1950s, Lolita has been reviled for its immoral content as well as celebrated for its aesthetically seductive style. Does the first-person narrator's nympholepsy, the highbrow term he uses for his sexual obsession with girls on the verge of puberty, implicate the author Nabokov as well, and in what ways? How does the novel relate to present-day discussions about pedophilia and about sexual consent? Can a nympholeptic narrator with the dubious name of Humbert Humbert be viewed as reliable in any way? Are his observations on the cultural inferiority complex of Americans vis-a-vis Europeans relevant today? Weekly reading assignments will be relatively short to allow for the close reading on which the discussion will be based and videos of ex Stanley Kubrick's 1962 Lolita and the 1997 Lolita with Jeremy Irons will be shown in class.
Books (for catalog) 1: Vladimir Nabokov|Lolita|Vintage international Paperback|1989|x
Readings catalog text: Readings: This edition only: Vladimir Nabokov, Lolita (Vintage international Paperback, 1989).
course_info_string: Estimated outside work is three hours per week. Class size is limited to 22.
other_req_materials: Excerpts from Stanley Kubrick's 1962 Lolita film and the 1997 Lolita with Jeremy Irons will be shown in class.
other_readings: Questions and topics related to each week's reading will be posted on the course website.
sgl_bio_1: Katherine O'Connor taught Russian and Comparative Literature at Boston University. She looks forward to discussing Lolita with readers who remember 1950s America.
Colloquium Room: I cannot use the Colloquium Room.
special_req: I like the seminar rooms with long tables.
further_info: I gave this course three years ago in Spring 2016, and Lolita's provocative brilliance never seems to dim. I'm more than anxious to teach it again.

title: Self and Culture Through Cinema
course_desc: We will view six feature films and discuss what the director had in mind as well as what they tell us about culture and human nature. These movies were chosen more for what they demonstrate about a culture and less for emotional impact. Each movie will be viewed one week and discussed the next. Online readings will be provided to enrich discussions and some movie scenes will be replayed to enhance memories. There will be two movies from Denmark both involving dysfunctional families, two movies from Iran both involving people solving a common problem, and two movies from Japan both involving how office workers interact in and out of their workplaces. All movies are subtitled. This will be a morning class and it will be necessary to start it half an hour early on some movie days.
course_info_string: Estimated outside work is one hour per week. Class size is limited to 25.
other_readings: Online reading will include reviews,  postings by expats (foreigners living in Denmark, Iran, or Japan and occasionally natives of those countries living in the U.S.), and magazine articles.
sgl_bio_1: J Adrian Zimmer is from Nebraska and has lived in Canada, Denmark, and Iran. He has a large collection of foreign and art house movies. He taught a course similar to this one last spring.
Additional Schedule Information: Any morning slot will do.  The morning is necessary so we can sometimes start early without disrupting other activities.
Colloquium Room: I strongly prefer the Colloquium Room.
special_req: I believe movies shown on larger screens have a greater impact.
further_info:
The description of this course reflects things I learned from my previous course "Other Cultures Through Cinema".   However none of the movies are repeats.

In the order I intend to show them, here are the movies:

From Denmark:  "Minor Mishaps" directed by Annette K. Olesen and released in 2002. "The Celebration" directed by Thomas Vinterberg and released in 1998.

From Iran: "Children of Heaven"  directed by Majid Majidi and released in 1999.  "About Elly" directed by Asghar Farhadi and released in 2009.

From Japan: " Ikiru" Akira Kurosawa and released in 1952.  "The Great Passage" directed by Yûya Ishii and released in 2013.

title: The Muse and the Money: Colette and Willy
course_desc: How does an impoverished woman of talent working under the harshest of conditions become an accomplished writer? The French writer Sidonie-Gabrielle Colette married a man fourteen years her senior in 1893.  She was twenty and he was almost thirty-four, a jaded man-about town. Henri Gautier-Villars: Parisian author, publisher, and libertine, pen name "Willy," made his living off a stable of poorly paid writers whose work he published in his own name. Though in the course of her career, Colette was to become a celebrated literary icon, she was fresh from a backwater in Burgundy when she married him. Ignorant of Parisian ways, she found herself broke and alone as her husband cavorted with other women. Dependent on Willy for her every need, she could only go along when he locked her in a room to force her to write the Claudine stories, the first of her career. Willy published them in his own name, secured the copyright, and used the money from their enormous success to support a lavish lifestyle while his wife lived in penury. In "The Muse and the Money" we'll read about this time in Colette's life and discuss how she survived. We'll watch the 2018 film, "Colette," and we'll study her first four stories, the Claudine series.
Books (for catalog) 1: Colette|The Complete Claudine|Farrar, Straus and Giroux|2001|x
Books (for catalog) 2: Colette|My Apprenticeships (OUT OF PRINT) available on bookfinder.com|Penruin Books|1967|x
Readings catalog text: Readings: Only these editions: Colette, The Complete Claudine (Farrar, Straus and Giroux, 2001); Colette, My Apprenticeships (OUT OF PRINT) available on bookfinder.com (Penruin Books, 1967).
course_info_string: Estimated outside work is two hours per week. Class size is limited to 25.
other_req_materials: Handouts: If there's time: one or two articles on the Claudine stories.
sgl_bio_1: Susan LaDue discovered Colette while teaching French at UMass, Boston. The field of women's studies was just getting started, so Susan read everything that Colette wrote so she would know what she was talking about when lobbying other faculty to include the French writer in the Women's Studies curriculum. Fascinated by the author's early years, Susan published a paper about Colette's struggle to survive.
Additional Schedule Information: Tues, Wed, and Thurs afternoons are possible, but more difficult.
Colloquium Room: I can use the Colloquium Room if that is the only way to accommodate my class size and schedule.
special_req: I need a room where I can show a film.
further_info: Presentation of context and background will be mixed with discussion of the assigned reading.  Discussions will be structured by questions which I'll distribute before the relevant session.

title: Garden Through Time
course_desc: From Peru to the American Colonies, a selection of six gardens are selected.  Created from 1500 to 1722, they include Machu Picchu, Incan Patchacuti’s royal estate; Villa Lante, the country estate of Cardinals Gambara and Montalto; Shalimar Bagh, Shah Jahan’s Kashmir retreat; Katsura Imperial Villa, Kyoto, Japan; Vaux le Vicomte, Nicolas Fouquet’s masterpiece, and Thomas Jefferson’s Monticello.  The class will explore the design of space and background culture of each garden through presentation and  class discussions.  Homework will  be readings from the text and handouts together with viewing of posted videos.
Books (for catalog) 1: Moore, Mitchell, Turnbull|Poetics of Gardens|MIT||Yes
Readings catalog text: Readings: This edition only: Moore, Mitchell, Turnbull, Poetics of Gardens (MIT, ).
course_info_string: Estimated outside work is two hours per week. Class size is limited to 25.
other_req_materials: Other readings will be prepared as handouts. Selected videos
sgl_bio_1: Rick Lamb is a landscape architect.  Rick continues to enjoy an active practice and wide-ranging travel schedule
Colloquium Room: I strongly prefer the Colloquium Room.
special_req: I enjoy Colloquium Room for an ease of seating for discussion
further_info: I would set as a class goal for the class to br interested in both garden design and the associated culture

title: Jorge Luis Borges: The Argentine Short Story Master
course_desc: Jorge Luis Borges (1899-1986) exploded into the English-speaking world in the 1960s as part of the so-called "Boom" of Latin American writers.  More accurately, the "boom" was the explosion of American and European recognition of talent that had been at work for many years.  Our world discovered them decades after they had begun writing. Borges, like many of his contemporaries, was sophisticated, world-traveled, multi-lingual, and multi-talented.  His intellectual interests lay in European thought and philosophy - English, German, Spanish, and French.  HIs literary interests were even more widespread, American, Scandinavian, Anglo-Saxon, Irish nationalist, Eastern European, and Near Eastern.  We shall see all these elements in what we tackle. The short stories make up in intensity for their brevity.  They are fun, bizarre, curious, and profound.  Discussions depend on our collective imaginations and our willingness to walk through the looking-glass.  Brush up on your medieval Arabian history, the Kabbala and Irish uprisings!  Philosophy majors welcomed.
Books (for catalog) 1: Borges, Jorge Luis|Ficciones|Grove Press|1994|x
Books (for catalog) 2: Borges, Jorge Luis|The Aleph and Other Stories|Penguin|2004|xNo
Readings catalog text: Readings: Only these editions: Borges, Jorge Luis, Ficciones (Grove Press, 1994); Borges, Jorge Luis, The Aleph and Other Stories (Penguin, 2004).
course_info_string: Estimated outside work is two hours per week. Class size is limited to 20.
other_req_materials: An occasional link to incidental photos or brief lists will be available online from the course syllabus.  Short essays and poems will be posted online.
other_readings: The texts are very dense and there are at least five to 10 stories per session!  More reading would be a burden.  Photos of Buenos Aires in the 20s and 30s.  Tango and milonga recordings.  Archival photos of Borges.  Some brief intro. lectures on Borges's life and world.
sgl_bio_1: Richard Berger has never has never seen my name.  I can say that a foreign government co-opted  12-year old Richard into Venezuelan politics in 1953. He was fully immersed in the Latin American world ever since. Yes, innocently taking Spanish courses as if it were a random academic choice. But six years? Let us not be so credulous! And his studies abroad? I should say! He was operating in Peru for his first palace revolution in 1962. Was present at the Christian Democratic Chilean landslide of 1964 and breezily walked through a Buenos Aires park as another military leader was sacked in 1970. Three innocent years abroad? Coincidence? I think not. After untold visits to Central, Caribbean and South America and though in deep undercover for the last forty years--in public schools he says--drilling in Spanish colonial history, national transformations, social revolutions, and the Spanish language, the secretive don Ricardo has disavowed me, us, his handlers, and has retired to a simpler life disentangling Latin American reality. Any SGL is out of our control. This one wants to help you know what an imagined life is like. Was don Ricardo ever real? Does I exist?
Colloquium Room: I cannot use the Colloquium Room.
special_req: Very flexible on rooms save for the CR.
further_info:
This course was given as the first half of a Fall 2013 12-week course "Three short story masters: Borges, Cortázar and García Márquez."  HILR members who previously took that course are advised NOT to enroll in this one.

Each set of readings is accompanied by a series of open-ended questions about meaning, structure, language, pace, and context.  Class depends on participant observations based on textual references.  In addition, Borges indirectly asks "What is fiction, what is real, what is a reader, and what is a writer?"  If Borges writes a story in which he appears, is he "real" or part of the fiction?  Even better, does the reader change as s/he reads?

All questions are welcomed!  The class will approach the answers.

title: From the Big Bang to the Big Rip
course_desc: We will explore the big picture, the really big picture, provided by contemporary cosmology. We will see how the theory of general relativity provides alternative possibilities of how the universe might evolve. We will discuss observations that show that the universe has been expanding since its origin in the Big Bang and key clues about the earliest expansion of the universe. We will consider the origin of the elements, the evolution of stars and galaxies as the universe has aged, and the roles played by black holes and neutron stars and by “dark matter” and “dark energy". Finally we will investigate speculative ideas about what set off the Big Bang and what the fate of the universe might be, including the possibility that the universe might ultimately fly apart in the Big Rip! Classes will consist of lectures and lots of discussion. The course is intended for both scientists and humanists.
Books (for catalog) 1: Delia Perlov and Alex Vilenkin|Cosmology for the Curious|Springer|2017|
Readings catalog text: Readings: Delia Perlov and Alex Vilenkin, Cosmology for the Curious (Springer, 2017).
course_info_string: Estimated outside work is two hours per week. Class size is limited to 22.
other_req_materials: Additional articles will be provided on-line
sgl_bio_1: William Blumberg has a PhD in physics and has led HILR courses on cutting edge topics in physics, astrophysics, and astrobiology including quantum mechanics, particle physics, black holes, and the origin of life.
Additional Schedule Information: Please do not schedule at the same time as the course proposed by Murray Smith et. al.
Colloquium Room: I can use the Colloquium Room if that is the only way to accommodate my class size and schedule.
further_info: I have experience leading successful science courses that included study group members with the full range of backgrounds at HILR - from holders of PhD's in physics and math to social workers and interior designers.

title: To Save the World: Two Philosophical Novels of Daniel Quinn
course_desc: Coming at the start of Ishmael, the strange ad, “TEACHER SEEKS PUPIL. Must have an earnest desire to save the world. Apply in person,” will start us on a voyage back to beginning of human civilization. In the two novels we will read, Quinn lays out his argument for the social and environmental malaise increasingly visible in our time on Earth. The Story of B continues to poke holes in modern beliefs and points to ways out of its failings. The two novels form a parable about modernity, its origins, and its problematic structure. We will use the books as an access to our hidden beliefs, and to some alternate ways to hold and heal the world. Be prepared for a roller-coaster ride, but don't expect a Forster or Hemingway novel. Discussion is essential.
Books (for catalog) 1: Daniel Quinn|Ishmael|Bantam|1995|
Books (for catalog) 2: Daniel Quinn|The Story of B|Bantam|1997|
Readings catalog text: Readings: Daniel Quinn, Ishmael (Bantam, 1995); Daniel Quinn, The Story of B (Bantam, 1997).
course_info_string: Estimated outside work is two hours per week. Class size is limited to 22.
other_req_materials: The SGL will provide additional materials, including extracts from his own, related work.
other_readings: I will add other materials to the course website to enrich the novel. I am still developing this course, but will follow much the same process as in my previous, well-received courses. I will have a full syllabus completed to use in preparing the course web site and in structuring the course overall.
sgl_bio_1: John Ehrenfeld is flourishing and also learning and writing about it (2+ books). This inquiry has taken him from his engineering roots into the realms of philosophy and biology, where he finds rich possibilities for a flourishing world.
Additional Schedule Information: I can generally do it on T, W, or Th. Subject to the qualification below,  I do prefer Wednesdays.
Colloquium Room: I can use the Colloquium Room if that is the only way to accommodate my class size and schedule.
special_req: I would like to be scheduled on the same day, but not at the same time, as the course Mark Yessian and Jim Whitten are planning to give. If that's not possible, just use my above preferences.
further_info: I have written 3 books about sustainability/flourishing (one is still forthcoming but might be out during the term) that have many parallel themes. Quinn's novel (sic) way to present them forces a different frame for discussion that is both challenging (good for a class like ours) and philosophically informative. I plan little lecturing and primarily discussion. I will have questions to seed the discussion. I would expect the discussion to touch on the current state of the social and natural world, but it is NOT designed as a critique of current politics.

title: Not the Western Front
course_desc: This course will take us away from the familiar literature of World War I—all situated on the Western Front, all immersed in trench warfare. Instead, our reading will reveal the war as fought on the Russian front, in the Italian Alps, and in what was then Mesopotamia, today’s Iraq. Not only the locales but the tones differ: idealistic and lyrical in Walter Flex’s “experience of war” in Poland, sober and damning in Emilio Lussu’s account of combat on the Asiago plateau, open yet imperial in the Indian Army medical officer W. A. Spackman’s memories of the worst British defeat of the war at Kut-al-Amara. Was there nevertheless a common war experience in 1914-1918? How do these works rank with the “classics” of the war? Discussion of such questions will be the core of the course. Brief background lectures and videos will be included.
Books (for catalog) 1: Walter Flex, Trans: Brian Murdoch|The Wanderer between the Two Worlds|Rott Publishing|2014|
Books (for catalog) 2: Emilio Lussu, Trans: Gregory Conti|A Soldier on the Southern Front|Rizzoli Ex Libris|2014|
Books (for catalog) 3: W. C. Spackman, Ed: Tony Spackman|Captured at Kut: Prisoner of the Turks|Pen and Sword Military|2008|
Readings catalog text: Readings: Walter Flex, Trans: Brian Murdoch, The Wanderer between the Two Worlds (Rott Publishing, 2014); Emilio Lussu, Trans: Gregory Conti, A Soldier on the Southern Front (Rizzoli Ex Libris, 2014); W. C. Spackman, Ed: Tony Spackman, Captured at Kut: Prisoner of the Turks (Pen and Sword Military, 2008).
course_info_string: Estimated outside work is three hours per week. Class size is limited to 12.
other_readings: I plan to use videos in class that will, beyond the books, be subjects for discussion.  I have already located some, will search out others.  I found videos to be useful in the class I led last spring.  I will also list books about war on the fronts covered here for those who want to read further.
sgl_bio_1: Dan White taught and wrote about the First World War while a Professor of History at the University at Albany and has been particularly drawn to first person accounts of the front experience like those chosen for this class.
Additional Schedule Information: Any time on Tuesday, Wednesday or Thursday not chosen above
small_room: My previous class was this size, and we could all sit around a long table, which facilitated discussion as class members all faced one another.  It was also easy to show the videos I used.
special_req: If there would be strong demand for the class I would be willing to go up to 18.

title: Frauds “R” Us -- Deceiving Silicon Valley
course_desc: Theranos, a company founded to carry out innovative blood testing, quickly became a detective story and cold-blooded corporate fraud saga worthy of a crime thriller. Founder Elizabeth Holmes cultivated all the qualities of start-up CEOs, and a contract with a pharmacy giant made her an overnight billionaire. Luminaries from government (George Schultz), media (Rupert Murdoch), and law (David Boises) contributed to the company’s ascent. But the business was all an illusion based on trickery, which was uncovered only by a Wall Street Journal reporter’s relentless digging. We will discuss how the Theranos fraud was constructed, how the company fought back against increasingly bad news, and why venture investors were duped. We will also look at the ingredients of previous frauds based on new technologies, and explore whether Elon Musk’s business empire might share some characteristics with Theranos. No investment knowledge necessary.
Books (for catalog) 1: John Carreyrou|Bad Blood: Secrets and Lies in a Silicon Valley Startup|Penguin Random House|2018|
Readings catalog text: Readings: John Carreyrou, Bad Blood: Secrets and Lies in a Silicon Valley Startup (Penguin Random House, 2018).
course_info_string: Estimated outside work is two hours per week. Class size is limited to 22.
other_req_materials: The SGL will post recent business press articles and podcasts on other questionable technology financings on the course website.
other_readings: The course will also include videos covering the company's push-back in the press, including the Space Invaders-style video game Theranos engineers developed using a photo of the WSJ reporter's head as a target.
sgl_bio_1: Steven Harvey has led HILR study groups on frauds and financial crises. He is by trade an investment analyst and portfolio manager, and is especially drawn to the human dramas within financial calamities.
Colloquium Room: I cannot use the Colloquium Room.
further_info: The book is a highly-entertaining first-person account by the reporter who uncovered the fraud; we'll read about 60 pages each week throughout the course.   I expect to supplement it with a weekly media article or two to place Theranos in the grand tradition of frauds based on new technologies.  I am not planning on using academic journal articles.

title: Why the Germans? Why the Jews?
course_desc: We will contrast divergent views of German Jews before 1933 by reading two books that survey the history of German Jews before the Nazis and the Holocaust from the German and Jewish perspective. We will consider both sides of German Jews’ history and ask ourselves about historical inevitability, prediction, and responsibility. The books ask how the Holocaust could have happened. Aly poses the questions explicitly in his title, and he surveys German attitudes toward Jews since the emancipation of the Jews by Napoleon. Elon only alludes to the Holocaust in his title, but he also ends his exposition in 1933. We will conclude our discussions with a few possible parallels in today’s world, even though they may be somewhat less extensive in scope or international impact.
Books (for catalog) 1: Götz Aly|Why the Germans? Why the Jews?|Henry Holt|2014|
Books (for catalog) 2: Amos Elon|The Pity of It All|Henry Holt|2002|
Readings catalog text: Readings: Götz Aly, Why the Germans? Why the Jews? (Henry Holt, 2014); Amos Elon, The Pity of It All (Henry Holt, 2002).
course_info_string: Estimated outside work is two hours per week. Class size is limited to 20.
other_req_materials: Articles, book chapters, and newspaper articles will be posted as PDF files on the study group web site.
sgl_bio_1: Peter Temin has led many study groups at HILR on varied topics. He has written about the economy of the 19th century and the interwar years in many forms. His aim in study groups is to have extensive discussions about the assigned readings.

title: Constitutional Originalism: The Conservative Counter Revolution
course_desc: Constitutional originalism is in ascendance. As a doctrine of judicial review, it now exerts far-reaching influence in our lives and commands attention in legal and political circles, coffee shops, and even theaters. In this course, we will come to grips with its meaning, origins, emergence as a politically propelled reaction to the activist Supreme Court of the 1950s and 1960s, and ensuing contemporary consequences. As we must, we will give major attention to the foremost originalist of our time: Antonin Scalia. A variety of perspectives and sources, most especially Scalia’s book, A Matter of Interpretation, will be examined. Finally, to sharpen our understanding, we will review the contrasting perspectives of Justice Scalia and Justice Stephen Breyer, who takes a more activist, living approach to Constitutional interpretation. This will be a discussion-focused course.
Books (for catalog) 1: Antonin Scalia|A Matter of Interpretation: Federal Courts and the Law|Princeton UP|2018|X
Readings catalog text: Readings: This edition only: Antonin Scalia, A Matter of Interpretation: Federal Courts and the Law (Princeton UP, 2018).
course_info_string: Estimated outside work is four hours per week. Class size is limited to 20.
other_req_materials: Additional materials, including articles, YouTube links, speeches, excerpts from court cases, and more will be posted on the course website.
sgl_bio_1: Mark Yessian has led HILR study groups addressing constitutionalism, political history, and political philosophy for the insights they shed on contemporary politics and public policy challenges.
sgl_bio_2: James Whitters has led HILR study groups addressing the judicial philosophies of Supreme Court judges for the insights they reveal about the institutional activities of the Court and the practice of Constitutional interpretation.
Colloquium Room: I cannot use the Colloquium Room.
special_req: Prefer a room with a table. Rm 202 is good with a class size limited to 20. If the room next door with a table is available, a class size of 25 would be acceptable.

title: The Birth of the Modern Middle East
course_desc: The Middle East was for centuries the incontestable reservoir of scientific and ideological innovations. In lectures and discussion, this study group will analyze its transformation from the ashes of World War I into a different, modern Middle East. The dissolution of the Ottoman Empire after the prolonged war on the Eastern fronts established the seeds of the area's discontent. Our class will study the fast-moving events in which the Ottoman Empire simultaneously took on Russian, British, and French troops; political intrigues topped the agenda of European powers; and diplomatic and intelligence activities were at their peak. The Sykes-Picot Agreement, the Hussein-McMahon Correspondence, the Balfour Declaration, the Cairo Conference all attempted to establish a "Peace to End All Peace." However, in reality, these agreements established a set of unsustainable governance systems based on incomprehensible and unacceptable principles in the eyes of the local populations.
Books (for catalog) 1: Eugene Rogan|The Fall of the Ottomans: The Great War in the Middle East|Basic Books|2015|
Readings catalog text: Readings: Eugene Rogan, The Fall of the Ottomans: The Great War in the Middle East (Basic Books, 2015).
course_info_string: Estimated outside work is three hours per week. Class size is limited to 25.
other_req_materials: The SGL will post additional materials, such as the Sykes-Picot Agreement and the Hussein-McMahon Correspondence, on the class website.
sgl_bio_1: George Theodosiou is a political refugee who practiced and taught cardiology during his professional career. Since joining HILR, he has led numerous study groups on the history of the Balkans, Russia, the Levant, Byzantium, and the Ottoman Empire.
Additional Schedule Information: 10 weeks; would like to start and end early in the semester.
Colloquium Room: I strongly prefer the Colloquium Room.
special_req: Full complement technology.
further_info: This is a repeat study group from a previous offer with a sizable waiting list.

title: Hemingway: A Farewell to Arms
course_desc:
Ernest Hemingway’s “A Farewell to Arms” was published in 1929.  The novel was immediately banned in Boston by the Boston police.  It is both a war story and a love story.  It involves an American, Frederick Henry and his experience in the Italian Army during World War 1.  Henry is wounded, and is brought back to health by a nurse ( Catherine Barkley) in a Milan hospital.  The two fall in love, and the novel traces the story of their ill-fated romance.  “A Farewell to Arms” is arguably Hemingway’s finest book.  It features his best writing: his most famous passages are contained in the book.  If “The Sun Also Rises” was the novel that made Hemingway famous, “A Farewell to Arms” made him wealthy.

We will conduct a slow reading of the novel.  We will also read a handful of Hemingway short stories that may bear light on the development of “A Farewell to Arms.”
Books (for catalog) 1: Ernest Hemingway|A Farewell to Arms|Scribners|2012|A Farewell to Arms, the Hemingway Library Edition
Readings catalog text: Readings: This edition only: Ernest Hemingway, A Farewell to Arms (Scribners, 2012).
course_info_string: Estimated outside work is two hours per week. Class size is limited to 12.
other_readings: Hemingway short stories and various handouts will be provided by the SGL.
sgl_bio_1: john Clarke is an attorney.  He has presented academic papers at Hemingway conferences in France, Spain, Italy, Switzerland and the United States.
Additional Schedule Information: No
small_room: I do not plan to show movies or slides.  The emphasis will be on discussion and a close reading of the novel.

title: Two by Eugene O'Neill: The Late Plays
course_desc: “I knew it, I knew it. Born in a hotel room, died in a hotel room,” remarked American playwright Eugene O’Neill on his deathbed in the Boston Sheraton. During his lifetime, he wrote over 50 plays, many of them drawn from his difficult life. When he died in 1953, this Pulitzer and Nobel Prize-winning playwright was largely forgotten by the theatergoing public. Long Day’s Journey into Night was produced in 1956 and sparked renewed interest in his life and work.  This play and A Moon for the Misbegotten are two of his dramatic masterpieces. What do these plays tell us about the playwright and his craft? We will read, view, and analyze them in the context of the author’s personal life.
Books (for catalog) 1: Eugene O'Neill|Long Day's Journey into Night|various||
Books (for catalog) 2: Eugene O'Neill|A Moon for the Misbegotten|various||
Readings catalog text: Readings: Eugene O'Neill, Long Day's Journey into Night (various, ); Eugene O'Neill, A Moon for the Misbegotten (various, ).
course_info_string: Estimated outside work is two hours per week. Class size is limited to 22.
other_req_materials: Additional materials will be posted on the course website.
other_readings: Optional reading will include resources such as www.eoneill.org.
sgl_bio_1: Mary Kelley worked in the New York theater in management for many years before escaping to New England. She saw Long Day's Journey in its premiere production in 1956 and has been fascinated with O'Neill ever since.
Colloquium Room: I cannot use the Colloquium Room.
further_info: I am still in the planning stages!  I anticipate discussing O'Neill's life  course and having the class read Long Day's Journey for preparation for  at Sessions 2 and 3.  We will read a few scenes in class to experience how O'Neill's dialogue actually sounds to actors performing them. Then we will watch over two sessions (because it is long and also to allow discussion time) Long Day's Journey with Ralph Richardson, Katherine Hepburn, Jason Robards, Jr. and Dean Stockwell.  We will use the same preparation for Moon for the Misbegotten and watch the DVD with Jason Robards, Jr.,  Colleen Dewhurst and Ed Flanders, over two sessions.

title: Not Advertised in Tourist Brochures: An Exploration of the West Indies
course_desc: If you’ve basked in the Caribbean sun, on a cruise or in a hotel, what did learn about the island nation(s) you visited? What shaped its history before Columbus, during the colonial period of slavery and beyond, up until the 20th century domination of the United States and global economics? Using a multi-disciplinary combination of published analysis, documentary film, music, and literature, this course will be a discussion-based exploration of the economic, political and social forces that have shaped the many fragmented island nations of the English- and French-Speaking Caribbean, a region that is fragmented in many respects that go far beyond geography. People of West Indian origin represent nearly 4% of the US population. Working alone or in pairs, you will adopt a notable West Indian – dictator, revolutionary, Nobel Laureate, Rastafarian musician – and make a brief presentation to the class. Preparation time: approximately 2 hours per week.
Books (for catalog) 1: Jean Rhys|Wide Sargasso Sea|Penguin Classics, 50th Anniversary ed.|2016|x
Readings catalog text: Readings: This edition only: Jean Rhys, Wide Sargasso Sea (Penguin Classics, 50th Anniversary ed., 2016).
course_info_string: Estimated outside work is two hours per week. Class size is limited to 20.
other_req_materials: "Life and Debt" (film narrated by Jamaica Kincaid to be shown in class); published articles, excerpts from books, and literature will be uploaded to the course website.
other_readings: As an illustration of the type of material that will be included, the committee might look at "Why Haiti Should be at the Center of the Age of Revolution," an Aeon Essay by Laurent Dubois, articles on the region in The Economist, short stories by V.S. Naipaul, Edwidge Danticat, etc.
sgl_bio_1: Beginning in 1969 through 1996, Maggie Huff-Rousselle lived in the Caribbean region four times (Bahamas, Haiti and the Eastern Caribbean); twice managed subregional projects in the Eastern Caribbean, and holds a PhD from the University of the West Indies.
sgl_bio_2: Anita Marshall grew up on the Caribbean island of Dominica. A sister and as well as family members who live on the island keep her abreast of current events. Over the years she had made many trips back to Dominica as well as to other islands in the Caribbean. Anita holds a B.A from Smith College and an MSW from Simmons School of Social Work.
Additional Schedule Information: We would consider the fall semester if the spring session it too crowded.
Colloquium Room: I can use the Colloquium Room if that is the only way to accommodate my class size and schedule.
further_info: We expect to engage members in a discussion and exploration of this complicated and poorly-understood region, deepening their understanding of the region, specific island nations, and how the region mirrors larger geopolitical forces.

title: Constitutional Originalism: The Conservative Counter Revolution
course_desc: Constitutional originalism is in ascendance. As a doctrine of judicial review it now exerts far-reaching influence in our lives and commands attention in legal and political circles, coffee shops, and even theaters. In this course, we will come to grips with (1) its meaning, (2) its origins, (3) its emergence as a politically propelled reaction to the activist Supreme Courts of the 1950's and 1960's, and (4) its contemporary consequences. As we must, we will give major attention to the foremost originalist of our time: Antonin Scalia. We will draw on a variety of perspectives and sources including the book in the Readings section above. To sharpen our understandings, we will review the contrasting perspectives of Justice Scalia and Justice Stephen Breyer who takes a more activist, living approach to Constitutional interpretation. In this discussion-focused course, expect 50 to 60 pages of reading a week.
Books (for catalog) 1: Antonin Scalia|A Matter of Interpretation (ppk)|Princeton University|2018|x
Readings catalog text: Readings: This edition only: Antonin Scalia, A Matter of Interpretation (ppk) (Princeton University, 2018).
course_info_string: Estimated outside work is four hours per week. Class size is limited to 20.
other_readings: Articles, Youtube links, speeches, and more.
sgl_bio_1: Mark Yessian has led courses addressing constitutionalism, political history, and political philosophy for the insights they shed on contemporary politics and public policy challenges.
sgl_bio_2: James Whitters has led courses addressing the judicial philosophies of Supreme Court judges for the insights they reveal about the institutional activities of the Court and the practice of Constitutional interpretation.
Additional Schedule Information: No
Colloquium Room: I cannot use the Colloquium Room.
special_req: For a class size of 20, we prefer Room 202 with a table. If the room next door were available, we could accept 25 members.

title: The Innovative Stories of Katherine Mansfield
course_desc: Katherine Mansfield was an unlikely person to emerge as a master innovator of the modern short story. An immigrant to England from colonial New Zealand and at odds with her affluent bourgeois family, she was impacted by major illness, the effects of the First World War, a restless, peripatetic lifestyle, and a fraught, conflicted love life. Yet she harnessed her powers to write short stories characterized by luminous detail and subtle nuances of tone that resist simple, definitive interpretation. As Mansfield maintained in a letter to Virginia Woolf, one of her fervent admirers, “‘What the writer does is not so much to solve the question but to put the question.’” Our focus will be on the close reading of several of her provocative, inventive stories. The class website will provide material on Mansfield’s biography and critical reception and excerpts from her copious letters and notebooks.
Books (for catalog) 1: Katherine Mansfield|Katherine Mansfield: Selected Stories|Oxford UP|2002 (reissued 2008)|X
Readings catalog text: Readings: This edition only: Katherine Mansfield, Katherine Mansfield: Selected Stories (Oxford University Press, 2002 (reissued 2008)).
course_info_string: Estimated outside work is two hours per week. Class size is limited to 18.
other_readings: I will use videos on YouTube about Mansfield's life, articles on her biography and critical reception, scanned or found on line, and excerpts from her letters and journals, all put on the class website.  This will be supplementary material to the reading of the stories.
sgl_bio_1: Sharon Hamilton has taught English at several colleges, Phillips Exeter Academy, and Buckingham, Browne & Nichols School. She is the author of Shakespeare’s Daughters and Essential Literary Terms. She has led seven previous HILR study groups.
Additional Schedule Information: I have other commitments on both Tuesdays and Wednesdays.  I would appreciate not having a Monday class next semester, as I do this term.
Colloquium Room: I cannot use the Colloquium Room.
further_info: This class will be based on close reading and open discussion, so holding the number to 18 is essential.

title: Alice Munro’s Short Stories: Exploring the Genre
course_desc: Recipient of the Nobel Prize in Literature in 2016, Alice Munro is recognized worldwide for her exploration of and experimentation with short story as a genre. Her stories can be challenging to understand because they draw on intricate connections of memories and experiences, past and present, often forming a kind of kaleidoscope. In this study group, we will seek to gain insights into the impact of her stories by analyzing and discussing distinctive characteristics of three types of short stories she writes. One category is autobiographical “stories,” narratives drawn from her life—what Munro calls “not quite stories.” Another is the first-person narrative with fictional components. The third type consists of longer and more complex stories—what she calls “odder stories that branch out a lot.” Group members will read two or three stories for each meeting; additional resources include reviews and interviews with Munro.
Books (for catalog) 1: Alice Munro|Family Furnishings|Vintage|2014|x
Readings catalog text: Readings: This edition only: Alice Munro, Family Furnishings (Vintage, 2014).
course_info_string: Estimated outside work is three hours per week. Class size is limited to 12.
other_req_materials: Additional information and readings will be posted on the course website.
other_readings: Handouts will be used for group activities; e.g., excerpts from reviews of Munro stories
sgl_bio_1: Joanne Carlisle began her career as a high school English teacher and subsequently focused on the study and teaching of reading. She has lead study groups on Austen's Northanger Abbey, Munro's Family Furnishings, and William Trevor's stories.
small_room: The method of study is discussion, and discussion is most effective in a small group around a table; this arragenemtn enables participation of all members.

title: Your Privacy, Your Security, Who's Watching and Why
course_desc: We the people of the world, rich and poor, are now online, and a revolution has occurred in the amount of data available about us. Data can be obtained on where we live, the status of our health, and what we do in our daily life. Like any revolution, this one has positive aspects as well as drawbacks. Our study group is about the scope and implications of the explosion in data generation, collection, and analytics. We will consider how to reap the benefits without sacrificing our privacy, security, liberty, or civic values. Our discussions on the assigned readings will be light on technology and focus more on history, policy, and law. SGMs will additionally be asked to research and present pertinent news on data collection issues, news that is published and heard every day.
Books (for catalog) 1: Michael Chertoff|Exploding Data: Reclaiming Our Cyber Security in the Digital Age|Atlantic Monthly Press|2018|
Books (for catalog) 2: Cyrus Farivar|Habeas Data: Privacy vs. the Rise of Surveillance Tech|Melville House|2018|
Readings catalog text: Readings: Michael Chertoff, Exploding Data: Reclaiming Our Cyber Security in the Digital Age (Atlantic Monthly Press, 2018); Cyrus Farivar, Habeas Data: Privacy vs. the Rise of Surveillance Tech (Melville House, 2018).
course_info_string: Estimated outside work is three hours per week. Class size is limited to 20.
other_req_materials: Additional readings and videos will be posted on the course website.
other_readings:
This is the beginning of  our syllabus.  We have many, many articles from magazines, blogs, newpapers, .... that we are collecting, too much to use, but some of it we will. SYLLABUS
  1. Chertoff: Introduction: Big Data is Watching You, Chapter 1, What is the Internet and How Did It Change Data
GOAL:  Set the context, go over examples that will be very relevant to SGMs
  1. Chapter Two, Chertoff:  How did Law and Policy evolve to Address Data 1.0 and0? and Chapter 1, Farivar:  Telephones: How a Fateful Call in 1963 from a Los Angeles Pay Phone Still Rings Clear Today
Goal:  Understand how policy and law have changed with the advances of technology by looking at the chronology of legal cases and laws
  1. Chapter Three, Chertoff: Data 3.0 and the Challenges of Privacy and Security AND Chapter Four, Farivar: When Big Brother Rides in the Back Seat.
GOAL:  Looking at current technology in wide or limited use to understand the challenges of Privacy and Security
  1. Chapter Four, Chertoff: Reconfiguring Privacy and Security in the Data 3.0 Universe and Chapter Three, Farivar: How One mugger’s Calls Helped Create the NSA’s Post-9/11 Phone Metadata Surveillance Program
GOAL:  Understanding Surveillance and Search and why there needs a  balance between privacy and safety of citizens
  1. Chapter 5, Chertoff: Data 3.0 and Controls on Private Sector Use of Data
GOAL: To understand what private organizations collect, how they store it, and how you can be aware of what they are doing.
  1. Chapter Six, Chertoff: Data 3.0 and Sovereignty: A Question of Conflict of Law
  2. A speaker
  3. Chapter 7, Chertoff: Cyber Warfare: Deterrence and Response
  4. Chapter from Farivar
  • Conclusion, Chertoff: Meeting the Challenge of Data 3.0: Recommendations for Law and Policy and Chapter 10, Farivar: Why Privacy Needs Us and Chapter 11, Farivar: Who Watches the Watchers
sgl_bio_1: Jean Bonney had a career in information technology and computer science. Since joining HILR, she has become very interested in environmental and sustainability issues as well as technology and mathematics. She has led many study groups.
sgl_bio_2: Joan McGowan had a career in mathematics and higher education administration. She has  led study groups on mathematics, technology, environmental and sustainability issues, and the Hawaiian kings and queens.
Additional Schedule Information: Do to other constraints, we are unable to lead in the morning and on Tuesday, Jean volunteers
Colloquium Room: I can use the Colloquium Room if that is the only way to accommodate my class size and schedule.
