title: Reading The New Yorker, Part 2
course_desc: Enhance and deepen your experience of reading The New Yorker by engaging with other SGMs in weekly discussions of readings from this esteemed publication of fiction and nonfiction articles. The primary goal of each class is to engage with others in thoughtful, spirited discussion of important current issues. Readings are chosen by SGMs based on class interest and topical relevance, and each SGM is encouraged to facilitate the discussion of one or two articles. Updated each week, the class website provides optional enrichment, including images, short articles, podcasts, reviews, YouTube clips, and maps. Since discussions are at the heart of our study group, each class member's participation is vital in contributing to the quality and depth of the class.
course_info_string: Estimated outside work is three hours per week. Class size is limited to 22.
other_req_materials: Current issues of The New Yorker magazine (print or online editions acceptable). Additional material related to the readings may be posted on the class page.
sgl_bio_1: Irene Fairley majored in English, received a doctorate from Harvard University, and taught linguistics and literature at the university level. She has led and co-led over a dozen study groups at HILR.
sgl_bio_2: Kate McGillicuddy majored in Art History, and received a Master's degree in Moderate Special Needs at Boston College. She has led multiple Study Groups at HILR, including non-traditional biographies, Reading The New Yorker, and most recently, Mary Shelley's Frankenstein.
Colloquium Room: I can use the Colloquium Room if that is the only way to accommodate my class size and schedule.

title: Labor, Social Control, and Slavery: The History of the Virginia Colony
course_desc: The story of the introduction of slavery in America is largely the story of slavery in Virginia. The Virginia Company of London was granted a charter by the King of England in 1606 to found the Virginia colony. The company's goal was to earn a profit; its original source of labor was the surplus poor of England, transported to Virginia to serve as indentured servants. From the beginning, getting these laborers to work and turning a profit proved difficult. Over time, the colony discovered tobacco as a cash crop and transformed its labor force from mostly white indentured servants to African American slaves. This is a discussion-based class that will focus on an acclaimed book by Edmund Morgan that details the history of the colony, the introduction of slavery, and the relationship between slavery and the founding of the Republic.
Books (for catalog) 1: Edmund Morgan|American Slavery, American Freedom|W.W. Norton|2003|
Readings catalog text: Readings: Edmund Morgan, American Slavery, American Freedom (W.W. Norton, 2003).
course_info_string: Estimated outside work is three hours per week. Class size is limited to 18.
other_req_materials: Podcasts from the radio documentary series Seeing White and excerpts from other relevant sources will be on the course website.
sgl_bio_1: Carol Pryor studied both American and European history and is interested in the relationships between the white and black working classes in the United States.
Colloquium Room: I cannot use the Colloquium Room.
further_info: I plan to run the class mainly through discussion based on questions I will distribute prior to each class.

title: An Astronomy Primer
course_desc: This study group will broaden and enrich your appreciation for our celestial environment while explaining the basic underlying science. The course will describe the role of astronomical influences in shaping many aspects of everyday life, such as calendars, time measurement, and navigation. It is particularly intended for individuals with little or no formal math or science background, and will exemplify the power of very basic physical concepts to explain the workings of the universe. Questions and requests for clarifications will be encouraged. We will explore four separate topic areas: our solar system and the universe beyond; the astronomy “toolbox” of special units of measure, vocabulary, and mapping the sky; astronomical phenomena, including the continually changing night sky, meteor showers, moon phases and eclipses; and human understanding and application of astronomically-based tools such as calendars, time-keeping, tides and celestial navigation.
Books (for catalog) 1: Marcia Bartusiak|Archives of the Universe|Vintage Books|2006|
Books (for catalog) 2: Ron Miller, William Hartmann|The Grand Tour, A Traveler's Guide to the Solar System, 3rd ed.|Workman Publishing|2005|x
Readings catalog text: Readings: Marcia Bartusiak, Archives of the Universe (Vintage Books, 2006); This edition only: Ron Miller, William Hartmann, The Grand Tour, A Traveler's Guide to the Solar System, 3rd ed. (Workman Publishing, 2005).
course_info_string: Estimated outside work is one hour per week. Class size is limited to 22.
other_req_materials: On the course website, various informational materials will be available for download; links to several online videos will also be listed.
sgl_bio_1: John Hopkins' physics education awakened his lifelong interest in astronomy. He has volunteered at the Museum of Science and local schools to convey the wonders of the universe to people of all ages and backgrounds.
Additional Schedule Information: Wednesday PM
Colloquium Room: I can use the Colloquium Room if that is the only way to accommodate my class size and schedule.
further_info: This course basically the same one I taught in 2015 and 2017, which was well received.  It has been modestly revised and updated to include new topics in astronomy, such as exoplanets and gravity waves.  Presentations will include images and outlines via PowerPoint.  Since it is primarily for astronomy virgins, I try address a few major points on each topic (planet, etc).  However, I do take very seriously the presentation of underlying physics concepts in a accessible (few equations) way.  Gravity, for example, is pretty straightforward, and the universe is basically driven by gravity.  Gravity waves, black holes, etc.  do not get more than a once-over.

title: Beauty and Fact: Topics in 19th Century Photography
course_desc: This course will examine major themes and topics in photography that emerged during the 19<sup>th</sup> century after the invention of the medium in the 1820s. Almost immediately, inventors saw the immense possibilities not only for the dissemination of ideas and communication, but also for applications based on documentary intent and aesthetic aspiration. We will explore the revolutionary shifts in image-making prior to the invention of photography and examine the processes of the primary inventors: Wedgwood, Talbot, Daguerre and Bayard. Topics will include aesthetic developments with the “art” of the photograph; documentary efforts of the early expeditionary photographers in the Middle East and Asia; depiction of colonial conflicts and the American Civil War; major art movements of Pictorialism and Naturalism; and the evolution of landscape photography as a genre unto itself. The format of the course will be slide lecture and discussion.
Books (for catalog) 1: Naomi Rosenblum|World History of Photography|Abbeville Press|2006|
Readings catalog text: Readings: Naomi Rosenblum, World History of Photography (Abbeville Press, 2006); ,  (, ).
course_info_string: Estimated outside work is three hours per week. Class size is limited to 18.
other_req_materials: Additional materials will be provided on the course website.
other_readings: Readings should be due prior to our meetings.
sgl_bio_1: Bonnell Robinson is a professor of photography and art history as well as a practicing photographer. She has taught courses on the history of photography and contemporary photo-based media for most of her teaching career.
Additional Schedule Information: I might.  I have to wait and see.
Colloquium Room: I cannot use the Colloquium Room.
special_req:
I need to look at the Colloquium Room more carefully.

Prefer a smaller room with AV because I think it encourages better dialogue and discussion.
further_info:
I am currently taking Susan Wexler's Rembrandt class and find that moving through the images we all find plenty to discuss.Hoping for a mix of presentation and discussion as we move through the work each week.  If the group becomes particularly interested in specific ideas, I would like to be flexible enough to accommodate their focus.

If this course seems like a go I would schedule a session at the Fogg Museum where we can look at original prints.  I also have some access to a few private collections from which I could borrow examples to bring in each week.

title: The Multicultural South: Its Literature and Culture
course_desc: What is "Southern" about Southern literature? Is there really a "Southern frame of mind," or is this a myth that Southerners harbor about their own uniqueness? We will study Southern culture through its love of storytelling, family, community, and place, as well as its obsession with military defeat, race, and class. From the earliest Native American Cherokee and Yuchi creation tales through colonial and Civil War narratives by slaves, whites, and Native peoples, we will see how early writers created a modern, multicultural Southern literature. Authors include old favorites like Twain, Faulkner, and Welty but also African-American authors Harriet Jacobs, Zora Neale Hurston, and Alice Walker and Native poets Joy Harjo (Muscogee) and Linda Hogan (Chickasaw). All members interested in Southern history and culture are welcome to a “down-home” discussion of the literature (fiction, plays, documentaries, poetry, and essays) of the American South.
Books (for catalog) 1: William Andrews|The Literature of the American South|W.W. Norton|1997|
Readings catalog text: Readings: William Andrews, The Literature of the American South (W.W. Norton, 1997).
course_info_string: Estimated outside work is two hours per week. Class size is limited to 25.
other_req_materials: Links to essays, movies, and other materials will be provided on the class website.
sgl_bio_1: Roberta Rosenberg, a carpetbagger from New York, has taught and written about Southern literature and culture for many years. She has a PhD in American Literature from the University of North Carolina.
Additional Schedule Information: I have a flexible schedule and can teach times other than those mentioned above.
Colloquium Room: I can use the Colloquium Room if that is the only way to accommodate my class size and schedule.
special_req: I prefer teaching in the round, not in rows. Any classroom that would accommodate that would be preferable.  I may want to show one documentary and would like a room that would allow me to use AV.  But I don't need the Colloquium room.
further_info: I have taught classes in Southern literature for many years on both the undergraduate and graduate levels.  However, this HIRL course would be a more low-key, participatory discussion class for members interested in cultural history and literature.  I will also bring in materials from other media:  music, documentary, etc.

title: Decoding the Secrets of the Air Around Us
course_desc: We take it for granted. We can’t see it, but we would die without it. The molecules of air we breathe are responsible for all life on earth and for the formation of minerals in the crust. This study group will trace the history of earth’s atmosphere, how the gases have evolved, and how these molecules have powered the engines of modern technology. We will take a tour through history to meet the discoverers and inventors who revealed the properties of our atmosphere and its uses. We have learned to use the air for our purposes but, at the same time, compounds introduced into the atmosphere can damage health and change the temperature of the atmosphere. We will read an acclaimed and entertaining account that unravels the science in layperson’s terms. Each class will begin with a visual presentation of the science followed by a question-based discussion of the issues.
Books (for catalog) 1: Sam Kean|Caesar’s Last Breath, Decoding the Secrets of the Air Around Us|Little, Brown|2017|
Readings catalog text: Readings: Sam Kean, Caesar’s Last Breath, Decoding the Secrets of the Air Around Us (Little, Brown, 2017).
course_info_string: Estimated outside work is two hours per week. Class size is limited to 20.
other_req_materials: Additional material and links to YouTube videos will be posted on the course website
sgl_bio_1: David Bliss, a retired scientist, has always had an interest in the history of planet earth. He has led study groups on materials science, plate tectonics, and history.
Colloquium Room: I can use the Colloquium Room if that is the only way to accommodate my class size and schedule.
further_info: I intend to have at least half of the time spent on discussion, including some elementary understanding of chemistry.  There are plenty of topics concerning safety and health about which anyone can have opinions.

title: On the Road: Writing About Your Travels
course_desc:
Do you enjoy travel? Writing? How about both? Perhaps you’d like to inform and entertain your friends (or the world) with accounts of your trips. Maybe you already do, but would like to sharpen your narratives. Or maybe you’d like to show off your work to other SGMs. This study group is intended to provide an opportunity for participants to focus on their travel writing skills. Methods will include;
  • Reading and discussing excerpts from the works of travel writers
  • Writing her/his own account of one or more trips
  • Discussing and critiquing each participant’s work….starting with the SGL’s
  • Listening to and interacting with guest speakers
course_info_string: Estimated outside work is two hours per week. Class size is limited to 18.
other_readings: The SGL will provide handouts. SGMs will be required to read each other's submissions.
sgl_bio_1: Steve MacQuarrie has written a couple books, though neither is about travel. He does, however, entertain friends with scribblings from his travel adventures.
Additional Schedule Information: I can do this most any time/day.
Colloquium Room: I can use the Colloquium Room if that is the only way to accommodate my class size and schedule.
special_req: I'd prefer to limit class size to 15.
further_info: In each of the last 5 sessions we'd spend 90 minutes discussing something that each of 3 students had written (i.e. 30 minutes on each). The other 30 minutes would be spent either discussing a work of a well known travel writer or listening to a guest travel writer. For the latter, I'd hope to enlist someone from the Globe and perhaps one other person. In the first session, we'd spend the first half of the class getting to know each other by having each of us describe her/his favorite travel spot and favorite travel writer. That discussion would help me identify which travel writers we'd discuss in subsequent sessions. We'd spend the second half critiquing something I'd written in the same way we'd discuss what the rest of the students had written in later classes, as well as discussing a work by a travel writer of my choosing.

title: Many Personae of Beethoven
course_desc: The prevailing image of Beethoven is undoubtedly that of a great heroic figure and his most famous pieces, such as the Third and Fifth Symphonies, validate that image. In fact, his music discloses multiple personae that display a much wider variety of feeling and temperament. Our objective is to focus on these several personae, as revealed in the music; to analyze what features of a particular piece convey humor, tragedy, or other moods; to expose SGMs to many of the composer’s less-heard compositions; and to address the difficult question of whether the music’s emotional content can be directly related to events in Beethoven’s life. The format will involve some lecture followed by listening and discussion. SGMs will be expected to listen to the compositions under discussion several times before coming to class, aided by the provided listening guides.
course_info_string: Estimated outside work is three hours per week. Class size is limited to 25.
other_req_materials: Background material and musical listening guides will be provided on the website. All musical assignments will be provided either as links available online or on CDs that will be distributed to each SGM.
sgl_bio_1: Jennifer Weininger received a MMus from the New England Conservatory of Music in history and theory of music. She has previously led HILR courses on A Deeper Understanding of Music and Music in Paris during the Third Republic.
sgl_bio_2: Stephen Weininger, a chemist and historian of chemistry, has a lifelong interest in music and has co-taught several musical courses in conjunction with his wife Jennifer.
Colloquium Room: I strongly prefer the Colloquium Room.

title: Nutrition and Healthy Aging
course_desc: Advice about nutrition comes at us from every angle, but this advices flipflops regularly, leaving us wondering what are the best dietary practices for healthy aging. This course will discuss the basic macronutrients and micronutrients in the diet, as well as current topics such as microbiome/probiotics, organic and modified foods, and food intolerances. Both popular and scientific literature will be approached in a critical manner, so that more informed decisions can be made about diet. Active participation will be encouraged through an online dietary analysis for SGM, and through selection of topics and articles by SGM.
Books (for catalog) 1: Walter Willett|Eat, Drink and Be Healthy|Free Press|2017|x
Readings catalog text: Readings: This edition only: Walter Willett, Eat, Drink and Be Healthy (Free Press, 2017).
course_info_string: Estimated outside work is two hours per week. Class size is limited to 20.
other_readings: There will be articles, online materials and handouts, as well as an online nutrition program.  Food samples to illustrate nutritional concepts will be provided during the break.
sgl_bio_1: Barbara Brodsky is a biophysicist/biochemist who has taught nutrition to medical students, and this is her first time as a SGL
sgl_bio_2: Barbara Smith Koff is a biochemist who has taught two previous HILR courses on Genetics.
Colloquium Room: I can use the Colloquium Room if that is the only way to accommodate my class size and schedule.
special_req: O

title: To Kill a Mockingbird: The Book and the Movie and Their Meaning Today
course_desc: Harper Lee's To Kill a Mockingbird has been a best seller since its publication in 1960. Parents named their sons Atticus, who, out of moral convictions, defended a black defendant against manufactured charges of raping a white woman. Go Set a Watchman, generally considered a first draft for Mockingbird, was published in 2015, a year before Lee’s death. The Atticus Finch in this book is a racist, someone from whom his daughter, returning from living in the North, recoils. This study group will explore the two books in depth while also analyzing the movie adaptation.  Why did Lee's original publishers reject Watchman and steer her toward writing what eventually became Mockingbird? Why did she portray Atticus as a folk hero in To Kill a Mockingbird but make him much less appealing in Go Set a Watchman? Can we still love Atticus Finch knowing what we know about his first characterization?
Books (for catalog) 1: Harper Lee|To Kill a Mockingbird|J. B. Lippincott|1960|
Books (for catalog) 2: Harper Lee|Go Set a Watchman|Harper Collins|2015|
Readings catalog text: Readings: Harper Lee, To Kill a Mockingbird (J. B. Lippincott, 1960); Harper Lee, Go Set a Watchman (HarperCollins, 2015).
course_info_string: Estimated outside work is two hours per week. Class size is limited to 20.
sgl_bio_1: Jon Small was Director of Programs for Massachusetts Continuing Legal Education where he oversaw the creation and delivery of over 300 seminars a year.  Jon has led five previous study groups on Baseball and American Culture, Walt Whitman, Paul McCartney, and The Beatles.
Colloquium Room: I can use the Colloquium Room if that is the only way to accommodate my class size and schedule.
further_info: Mostly discussion coupled with video viewing

title: Reading The New Yorker, Part 1
course_desc: Enhance and deepen your experience of reading The New Yorker by engaging with other SGMs in weekly discussions of readings from this esteemed publication of fiction and nonfiction articles. The primary goal of each class is to engage with others in thoughtful, spirited discussion of important current issues. Readings are chosen by SGMs based on class interest and topical relevance, and each SGM is encouraged to facilitate the discussion of one or two articles. Updated each week, the class website provides optional enrichment, including images, short articles, podcasts, reviews, YouTube clips, and maps. Since discussions are at the heart of our study group, each class member's participation is vital in contributing to the quality and depth of the class.
course_info_string: Estimated outside work is three hours per week. Class size is limited to 22.
other_req_materials: Current issues of The New Yorker magazine (print or online editions acceptable). Additional material related to the readings may be posted on the class page.
sgl_bio_1: Irene Fairley majored in English, received a doctorate from Harvard University, and taught linguistics and literature at the university level. She has led and co-led over a dozen study groups at HILR.
sgl_bio_2: Kate McGillicuddy majored in Art History, and received a Master's degree in Moderate Special Needs at Boston College. She has led multiple Study Groups at HILR, including non-traditional biographies, Reading The New Yorker, and most recently, Mary Shelley's Frankenstein.
Colloquium Room: I can use the Colloquium Room if that is the only way to accommodate my class size and schedule.
special_req:
This course works best in a Seminar Room where SGMs face one another across the table.

We have found this arrangement enhances discussion.
further_info: Please note that this is a submission for both Part 1 and Part 2. Let us know if we must submit two proposals. In the past one proposal has worked fine. If possible please include in each catalog entry the following: **Those wishing to enroll for a full 12 weeks must register for both Part 1 and Part 2.

title: Figaro, Figaro; Mozart vs. Rossini
course_desc: Two of the most famous and beloved Italian comic operas, Mozart's The Marriage of Figaro (1786) and Rossini's Barber of Seville (1816), share many of the same elements and characters, but present the viewer and listener with very different experiences although both are based on plays written by the French dramatist, Beaumarchais (1732-1799). We will learn how opera gives musical and dramatic expression to ideas about the self, society, and history. We will watch selected performances in class and view them in their entirety at home. Many say that Barber is purely comedic while Marriage adds drama and pathos. We shall explore those differences through viewing, listening, reading, and discussing the operas in class. This is not intended to be an advanced music course, and these two operas are excellent choices for newcomers to the magic of opera.
Readings catalog text: Readings: G.Shirmer, Collection of Opera Librettos, Giacchino Rossini's The Barber of Seville (G. Schirmer Inc, ); G. Shirmer, Collection of Opera Librettos, Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart, The Marriage of Figaro (G. Schirmer Inc, ).
course_info_string: Estimated outside work is two hours per week. Class size is limited to 20.
other_req_materials: The first chapter of Opera and Ideas from Mozart to Strauss, by Paul Robinson will be available for purchase from Gnomon Copy. Additional materials including librettos will be posted on the course website.
other_readings: Sgms will view the full operas at home. A local conductor of operas has agreed to address the class and a pianist and violist are being secured for occasional performances of opera segments.
sgl_bio_1: Valerie Arneson, in addition to her career as a biostatistician, spent many Saturdays taking the "opera bus" from Princeton to the Met for Saturday afternoon operas. She later lived in Milan for ten years and frequently went to operas at La Scala.
Additional Schedule Information: Thursday mornings  could work
Colloquium Room: I strongly prefer the Colloquium Room.
special_req: I will likely have occasional visitors, a performing musician and an opera conductor.
further_info: i will need assistance in organizing my curriculum and using technology, since this is the first course i have led.

title: The Human Cell
course_desc: The cell is the basic unit of life. Truly remarkable progress has been made in recent decades that reveals the structural and molecular components of cells and demonstrates the unique mechanisms whereby these microscopic entities perform functions critical to all life and human health. These cellular life units replicate, metabolize nutrients, migrate, assemble large molecules, conduct messages among and within themselves, protect us from infections, and adapt to their environment among other functions. This course will explore cell structures, components, and functions employing selected slides, videos, and assigned readings, the latter to include topic reviews available online as well as assigned cell biology textbook sources. The basic properties of molecules relevant to cell structure and function will be reviewed to set the stage for the course. Prior learning experiences in basic chemistry and/or prior HILR courses in biology will be helpful. The purpose of this course is to convey a general understanding of the cellular basis of life.
Books (for catalog) 1: Paul Sanghera|Molecular and Cellular Biology|Amazon Digital Services LLC|2015|
Readings catalog text: Readings: Paul Sanghera, Molecular and Cellular Biology (Amazon Digital Services LLC, 2015); ,  (, ); ,  (, ).
course_info_string: Estimated outside work is two hours per week. Class size is limited to 22.
other_req_materials: Brief text and video reviews on the various topics of this course will be posted on the course website. In some cases, printed excerpts on relevant topics will be distributed.
sgl_bio_1: Herbert Kagan is Emeritus Professor of Biochemistry at Boston University School of Medicine where he taught medical and graduate students and led NIH-sponsored research groups. He has led three previous HILR study groups.
Additional Schedule Information: I  have been requested to select a presentation day that differs from that of the previous presentation of this course, which I am happy to do, selecting from the three choices listed above.
Colloquium Room: I can use the Colloquium Room if that is the only way to accommodate my class size and schedule.

title: Sculpting the Earth: The Life and Work of Frederick Law Olmsted
course_desc: Anyone who has ambled through New York’s Central Park or Boston’s Emerald Necklace will appreciate the genius of Frederick Law Olmsted, America’s first true landscape architect. Olmsted’s work was ahead of its time, anticipating the ecological movement, the national park system, and the development of suburbs. This course will trace the circuitous path which led Olmsted to his true calling, a path that intersected the major historical events of 19<sup>th</sup> century America. It will cover a range of selected landscape projects and will explore the aesthetic and philosophical principles that guided Olmsted's work and draw heavily on quotations from Olmsted’s extensive correspondence. The SGL will employ a visual presentation format, but will also include weekly discussion questions and an optional field trip to the Olmsted National Historic Site in Brookline.
Books (for catalog) 1: Justin Martin|Genius of Place: The Life of Frederick Law Olmsted|Da Capo Press|2012|x
Readings catalog text: Readings: This edition only: Justin Martin, Genius of Place: The Life of Frederick Law Olmsted (Da Capo Press, 2012).
course_info_string: Estimated outside work is two hours per week. Class size is limited to 18.
sgl_bio_1: Al Levin has been fascinated by the environment, both natural and man-made, trying to understand what makes certain places magical. He has taught previous courses on Olmsted, the American West, and Charles Darwin.
Additional Schedule Information: Not really
Colloquium Room: I cannot use the Colloquium Room.
special_req: Room preference will depend on number of SGM's signing up.
further_info: I gave this course two years ago and thought that it was well received.  Check the course evaluations for confirmation.

title: Self-Portrait of the Artist from Albrecht Dürer to Lucian Freud
course_desc: Self-portraiture has a long and rich history in Western art, providing us with deep insights into artists' self-regard, regard for the viewer, and in some cases, the arc of physical maturation and ultimate decline. This class will study a broad selection of self-portraits from the 16th to 21st centuries, largely through printed and projected images, but will also feature one visit each to the Harvard Art Museums and the Museum of Fine Arts. At our final meeting, we will personally experience some of the challenges of self-portraiture with a hands-on sketch exercise.
Books (for catalog) 1: James Hall|The Self-Portrait: A Cultural History|Thames & Hudson|2016|x
Readings catalog text: Readings: This edition only: James Hall, The Self-Portrait: A Cultural History (Thames & Hudson, 2016).
course_info_string: Estimated outside work is two hours per week. Class size is limited to 18.
other_req_materials: Images projected during class will be made available online for class study and contemplation
sgl_bio_1: Len Sussman is a recently retired architect, with 40 years' experience in a broad range of building types, serving families, corporations, communities, and developers. He now returns to the interests - drawing and painting - that first inspired him to enter the practice of architecture. To that end, he shares in the management of the Boston Figurative Art Center, which offers open studio opportunities for both aspiring and experienced artists in the local area. He has exhibited his own work in a number of group shows and is busy developing a portfolio worthy of broader public attention.

special_req: Projection equipment and good viewing conditions are essential for this class

title: Lorenzo Da Ponte: A Man for All Stages
course_desc: Lorenzo Da Ponte: genius, con man, charlatan? The librettist for Mozart's operas Don Giovanni, Cosi fan tutte, and Marriage of Figaro, Da Ponte was a fascinating character who was born a Jew in Venice, became a priest following his father's conversion, and eventually moved to New York City. At different times a professional gambler, political agitator, court poet, and grocery store owner, Da Ponte was also the first priest to join the faculty of Columbia University and its first professor of Italian literature. What was it about Da Ponte that helped him succeed in whatever course he pursued? Do we find any motifs that run through his incredibly varied career? Come and enjoy the picaresque story of an enormously talented man with unsurpassed flair who was an indefatigable survivor. Selections from some of the operas of which he was the celebrated librettist will be shown in class. 50/50 discussion and presentation.
Books (for catalog) 1: Rodney Bolt|The Librettist of Venice, The Remarkable Life of Lorenzo Da Ponte|Bloomsbury|2006|
Readings catalog text: Readings: Rodney Bolt, The Librettist of Venice, The Remarkable Life of Lorenzo Da Ponte (Bloomsbury, 2006).
course_info_string: Estimated outside work is three hours per week. Class size is limited to 22.
sgl_bio_1: Ron Goodman was a programmer of classical music for his college radio station and the Concert Network. He wrote reviews for Boston publications including Bosarts Magazine. He is currently on the board of several Boston area classical music organizations.
Colloquium Room: I can use the Colloquium Room if that is the only way to accommodate my class size and schedule.
special_req: I will want to show portions of some operas, but I would not need extensive presentation facilities for slides, etc. If the class does catch on as did my coming class on Smart phone photography, then I could go up to 22 people and use whatever room could handle that. If not, we could go down as low as is necessary to fit into the appropriate room.

title: The Night Of
course_desc: Using the acclaimed HBO series, The Night Of, this course asks just how blind justice is. SGMs will watch video segments in class and follow the heartbreaking journey of a Pakistani-American student (Naz) from crime suspect to arrest, interrogation, court trial, and finally to his life afterward. The series also depicts the life-changing ordeal of his family and the struggles of his ambulance-chasing attorney. SGMs will encounter other characters as well: detectives, lawyers, a prosecutor, a judge, and morally ambiguous prisoners. We will view the case through their eyes as well as those of Naz and his family and discuss major themes including the purpose of bail, the lives of immigrants, and what it means to be a street cop. All these themes resonate within today's justice system. The course is also expected to include guest speakers representing police, prosecutors, and others involved in the criminal justice system.
course_info_string: Estimated outside work is two hours per week. Class size is limited to 20.
other_req_materials: Readings and other materials will be provided on the course website.
sgl_bio_1: Sandra Aylor's strong sense of social justice has led her to organize under-represented groups and to initiate local events supporting national issues.
Colloquium Room: I can use the Colloquium Room if that is the only way to accommodate my class size and schedule.
special_req: If enrollment is 12 or under small room is fine. I would like to use a microphone. And I would like to have a traveling mike to use for the SGM's questions and comments.
further_info: I need training in canvas and in IT in general. For the first portion of the class chairs arranged for viewing video. After break chairs arranged in semicircle for discussion. Readings will include New Yorker articles by Jennifer Gonnerman and Kalief Browder and The Guardian: Donald Trump and the Central Park Five, 2016. Segments of Notes From the Field will be posted.

title: Amazing Modern India
course_desc: India is becoming a successful economic and social powerhouse that is earning its place on the world stage. The growth is dynamic and yet there are problems, such as the caste system, the status of women, and communal unrest. But who can foretell India's future? The younger generation seeks to reconcile old traditions with new ambitions and dreams, but they face intensifying problems of inequality and pollution. This course will look at 21st century India through various lenses: stories of Indian families, tech innovators, entrepreneurs, Prime Minister Modi's leadership, and the new Hindu nationalism. We will examine the significant issues surrounding the upcoming elections of May 2019. With this background of Indian culture and its people, we will discuss India's strengths and weaknesses as well as its prospects for the future.
Books (for catalog) 1: Anand Giridharadas|India Calling, An Intimate Portrait of a Nation’s Remaking|St. Martin’s|2012|
Books (for catalog) 2: Rashmi Bansal|Take Me Home|Westland Ltd.|2014|
Readings catalog text: Readings: Anand Giridharadas, India Calling, An Intimate Portrait of a Nation’s Remaking (St. Martin’s, 2012); Rashmi Bansal, Take Me Home (Westland Ltd., 2014).
course_info_string: Estimated outside work is three hours per week. Class size is limited to 22.
other_req_materials: Pertinent articles from newspapers and magazines will be posted on the website.
other_readings: Some videos and YouTubes will be used as well as articles from the web.
sgl_bio_1: Wendy Reich has a PhD in anthropology with India as her area of expertise. She has lived and worked in India and was married there. She is very attached to the country and its people.
Colloquium Room: I cannot use the Colloquium Room.
further_info: I plan to do a segment on modern Indian politics, including the elections of 2014, and why Modi won and the Congress party lost and speculate about the upcoming elections May 2019. I would like to go into Hindutva and its perils, but also give a balanced view of Modi, his strengths and weaknesses and how he is doing, both at home and with respect to foreign policy. I will try to encourage lots of discussion. I have had very good luck with this in the past.

title: The Politics of School Reform
course_desc: How should we school America's children? Should the emphasis be on excellence? Individual development? Diversity? Fairness? Who should decide? Who should work in this profession, and who should pay for it? It used to seem as if nobody cared about public K-12 education. Now with cheating scandals, school closings, and teacher evaluations increasingly determined by student performance on state tests, more people are taking notice. The Federal government has attempted to help and influence beleaguered schools since the 1960s, but programs like No Child Left Behind and others have lured the press and partisan politics into the discussion. Opinions on charter schools, Common Core, and Teach for America have fractured long-standing educational alliances and led to unlikely bedfellows. Our readings, discussions, and visiting speakers will help us understand these issues as well as the challenges and hopes for the future.
Books (for catalog) 1: Dana Goldstein|The Teacher Wars: A History of America's Most Embattled Profession|Anchor|2015|
Books (for catalog) 2: Dale Russakoff|The Prize: Who's in Charge of America's Schools?|Mariner Books|2015|
Readings catalog text: Readings: Dana Goldstein, The Teacher Wars: A History of America's Most Embattled Profession (Anchor, 2015); Dale Russakoff, The Prize: Who's in Charge of America's Schools? (Mariner Books, 2015).
course_info_string: Estimated outside work is two hours per week. Class size is limited to 20.
other_req_materials: Additional materials will be made available on the course website.
sgl_bio_1: Nancy Sizer taught history in high schools for 25 years. She has been Co-Principal of a progressive charter school and has taught and written about school reform, especially in The Students Are Watching, with Theodore Sizer.
Additional Schedule Information: I am flexible when it comes to scheduling. I would also be able to lead in the second slot as well as the first next spring, but have plans to lead with nother sgl for fall 2019.
Colloquium Room: I cannot use the Colloquium Room.
further_info: My present plans are to follow the book and the development over time in the first hour, and discuss contemporary issues after the break. Of course this will depend to a certain extent on the sgms.

07 Oct 2018 4:20 pm: Ron Ebert
Very good topic, but no way to attack all those issues in six weeks - or even 12. Could she be assisted to  narrow her scope? Perhaps think of this as the first of a series of courses on edaction policy? How about our current education secretary? That would be worth a single course.07 Oct 2018 5:26 pm: Addison Stone
I agree with Ron that this is an important topic area, but that there is too much here. The book is quite good (Nancy used it in a study group two years ago, which I was in), but it too covers a lot of territory, and, inevitably, does so a bit superficially. Agree that zeroing in on a smaller set of issues would make sense, especially for a 6-week SG (the earlier one was 12 weeks). I’m also a bit worried about Nancy’s plan to devote the first hour of each session to discussion of material from the book (which is largely organized historically) and the second hour to “contemporary issues.” How will the two segments each week be connected? Will the additional readings help to bridge the gap? Asking her to give us examples of topics (for both the first and second hours) and readings for each of two weeks would help us see how she plans to organize the material.

Not sure how to punctuate the second sentence. The third sentence “Who should decide…” is quite awkward. Sentence beginning “With teachers’ unions…” is also awkward, even after “in part by” is changed to “in part on,” as it should be. Finally, in the last sentence: one doesn’t “hear from” films, and who are the visitors? Nancy invited visitors to her earlier SG on this topic, and the link to on-going topics was meager. This would be even more of a problem with only 6 weeks to devote to the material.
07 Oct 2018 8:29 pm: Barbara Burr
I love the idea of a study group on public school education, but this one leaves my head spinning. title: Boston's Gilded Age (1865-1900)
course_desc: In the years after the Civil War, Boston grappled with massive immigration from Europe, large-scale landfill projects, and substantial new construction. By 1900, Boston had changed from a small, ingrown community to a modern industrial city with beautiful parks, boulevards, museums, churches—and slums. We will examine the literature, art, and architecture of this new Boston, with due recognition given to its growing ethnic and religious tensions. An extraordinary generation of writers, artists, architects, and philanthropists created some of Boston’s best-loved institutions, including the Museum of Fine Arts, the Boston Public Library, the Gardner Museum, Trinity Church, the Back Bay landfill project, and the Emerald Necklace. We will study these monuments to civic pride as well as the less flattering fictional portraits by William Dean Howells, Sarah Orne Jewett, and Henry James. The study group will include two walking tours during class time of Beacon Hill and the Back Bay.
Books (for catalog) 1: Susan Wilson|Boston Sites and Insights|Beacon|2003|
Books (for catalog) 2: William Dean Howells|The Rise of Silas Lapham|Penguin Classics|1983|
Readings catalog text: Readings: Susan Wilson, Boston Sites and Insights (Beacon, 2003); William Dean Howells, The Rise of Silas Lapham (Penguin Classics, 1983); Henry James, The Europeans (Penguin Classics, 2008); ,  (, ); ,  (, ).
course_info_string: Estimated outside work is two hours per week. Class size is limited to 25.
other_req_materials: Additional required reading will be available in a course pack. There will be a $20 fee for tours of the Atheneum and the BPL. Note that any edition of The Rise of Silas Lapham and The Europeans is acceptable.
other_readings: I will be showing in class a movie of The Europeans, and we will take two tours of the Athenaeum and the BPL; we will also have two walking tours of Beacon Hill and the Back Bay.
sgl_bio_1: Martha Vicinus has been fascinated with the history, literature, and architecture of 19th century Boston ever since she moved here from the Midwest.  She leads walking tours for Boston by Foot. This is her 14th study group.
Colloquium Room: I cannot use the Colloquium Room.
further_info: This is a repeat of a course I gave Spring 2014 and 2015.  I've been asked to give it again several times.

title: Comedies by Coward
course_desc: Noel Coward dominated the English stage as its most prolific playwright and versatile talent for over 40 years. His plays epitomize the sophisticated British wit of the era between the two world wars. Today he is best known for his comedies, which portray members of high society as they intrigue and converse about their favorite subjects, primarily sex and marriage. We will read, view, and perform scenes from three of Coward’s most beloved works: Hay Fever, Private Lives, and Blithe Spirit. What do these comedies say about the artistic and social world of their time? How were they received by contemporary audiences and critics? What makes them so funny? Why are they still popular with audiences today? In addition to discussions about these questions and others, there will be some Noel Coward songs and surprises along the way.
Books (for catalog) 1: Noel Coward|Three Plays: Blithe Spirit, Hay Fever, Private Lives|Vintage International (paperback)|1999|x
Readings catalog text: Readings: This edition only: Noel Coward, Three Plays: Blithe Spirit, Hay Fever, Private Lives (Vintage International (paperback), 1999); ,  (, ).
course_info_string: Estimated outside work is two hours per week. Class size is limited to 25.
other_req_materials: Articles about Coward and the three plays will be posted on the course website.
other_readings:
Noel Coward songs will be played for the first minute or two of most classes.

Several short scenes from the plays on YouTube will be viewed in class.  There will also be performances of some scenes from the plays by members of the class.

Surprises -- a few brief but engaging interviews with directors of these plays will be viewed in class as well as a tour of a special exhibit on Noel Coward at the New York Public Library for the Performing Arts.
sgl_bio_1: Mickey Zemon has seen many wonderful productions of the plays of Noel Coward. She was the Library Director at Emerson College for 24 years and has led 15 study groups.

title: Things That Matter: Passions and Politics of a Conservative
course_desc: If there are gods in the world of conservative punditry, Charles Krauthammer sits atop the pantheon. Charles Krauthammer was a Pulitzer Prize-winning, weekly-syndicated columnist and an evening commentator on Fox News. Formerly a psychiatrist and Walter Mondale-supporting Democrat, he turned Reaganite in the 1980s. This study group will focus on topics in his book Things That Matter, a selection of Krauthammer’s best writings throughout the last 30 years. The discussion group will explore his commentary on national security, foreign policy, America’s role in the world, the post-Cold War world, as well as ethical and social issues. The class will be polled to help select topics of interest.  People often asked him, “How do you go from Walter Mondale to Fox News?” His answer was, “I was young once.” Join our discussion about what this brilliant, principled conservative had to say, and see if you are persuaded.
Books (for catalog) 1: Krauthammer, Charles|Things That Matter: Three Decades of Passions, Pastimes and Politics|Random House|2015|
Readings catalog text: Readings: Krauthammer, Charles, Things That Matter: Three Decades of Passions, Pastimes and Politics (Random House, 2015).
course_info_string: Estimated outside work is one hour per week. Class size is limited to 12.
other_readings: I plan to use a YouTube interview of the author discussing his book.
sgl_bio_1: Jim Sloman has attempted to draw upon history and politics, with occasional success, while navigating financial markets as an investor professionally and privately.
Additional Schedule Information: not this Spring
small_room: Given that we will be discussing op-eds and short articles by the author, a small class gives everyone time to contribute. If necessary I could expand this to 18 but would like to discuss with the committee.

title: Francis Crick: The Discovery of DNA and How It Works
course_desc: Francis Crick was one of the greatest scientific personalities of the last century. His breakthroughs at the boundary between life and non-life led to an understanding of life itself. We will read and discuss his wonderfully articulate autobiography, learning how he thought, collaborated, competed, and arrived at his “Aha!” moments. We will also read parts of the autobiography of James Watson and consider the roles of other contemporaries including Rosalind Franklin. The course is designed for those without a science background, but some “hard science” will be necessary to understand Crick’s elegant thought process and to feel his team’s sense of adventure. This will be carefully explained and there will be plenty of time for questions. We will ingest just enough molecular biology so that we can appreciate the paradigm shifts involved in these discoveries. We will watch the film DNA: Secret of Photo 51 as well as other short YouTube videos in class.
Books (for catalog) 1: Francis Crick|What Mad Pursuit|Basic Books|1990|
Books (for catalog) 2: James D. Watson|The Double Helix|Touchstone|2001|
Readings catalog text: Readings: Francis Crick, What Mad Pursuit (Basic Books, 1990); James D. Watson, The Double Helix (Touchstone, 2001).
course_info_string: Estimated outside work is two hours per week. Class size is limited to 22.
other_req_materials: Short autobiographical excerpts will be distributed or available as PDF files.

title: The 20th-Century American City
course_desc: Today more than 80% of Americans live in towns and cities, including over 70% who live in urban areas of over 50,000 people. Since 1900, a broad range of cultural, social, economic, and political forces have shaped the development of American metropolitan areas. These forces are reflected in the decisions about how and where all of us have chosen to live during the course of our lifetimes. This study group will look at American urban history during the last century, which has been characterized as involving three phases: central city ascendancy (1900-1945), central city decline and suburbanization (1945-1980), and post-suburban metropolis (1980-present). Although every American city has a unique character, which is a function of its history, location, demographics, culture, and economy, the trajectory of American urban development has been surprisingly consistent. Participants will be encouraged to connect their own lifestyle experiences to this urban planning framework, providing a mix of discussion and lecture elements.
Books (for catalog) 1: Jon Teaford|The Twentieth-Century American City: Problem, Promise and Reality, 3rd ed.|John Hopkins UP|2016|x
Readings catalog text: Readings: This edition only: Jon Teaford, The Twentieth-Century American City: Problem, Promise and Reality, 3rd ed. (John Hopkins University Press, 2016); ,  (, ).
course_info_string: Estimated outside work is three hours per week. Class size is limited to 22.
other_req_materials: In addition to the book, one to three required supplementary articles per session will be posted on the course website.
other_readings: 1. Supplementary readings will include newspaper/magazine articles and selected chapters of books. An example is the introductory chapter of The Power Broker: Robert Moses and the Fall of New York by Robert Caro. These will be made into PDFs attached to the on-line course outline in Canvas. A full list of these supplemental materials is still under development. Some videos may also be used in class including one or two episodes of Ken Burns’ “New York, New York”.
sgl_bio_1: Beverly Bookin was an urban planner in private practice for over 35 years in Portland, Oregon, where she worked on a broad range of large-scale public and private projects. She currently serves on the Gloucester Planning Board.
Additional Schedule Information: No.
Colloquium Room: I can use the Colloquium Room if that is the only way to accommodate my class size and schedule.
special_req: No preference as long as there is adequate audio-visual equipment. Obviously a small seminar room with a table will not accommodate 22 participants.
further_info: None that I can think of at this time.

title: Dangerous Products, Science, and Public Policy
course_desc: Why did it take so long to regulate well-known poisons like lead? What have been the roles of industry, science, and others in assessing and addressing the effects of these products on human health and the environment? This discussion course will examine the introduction of dangerous products into use, the evaluation of their effects, and the regulation of their use in the United States. Products to be considered include lead (water pipes, gasoline, and paint), asbestos, tobacco smoke, secondhand smoke, fossil fuels (acid rain and global warming), chlorofluorocarbons (ozone hole), DDT, vinyl chloride, and formaldehyde. We will discuss ways in which the use and regulation of these products may be influenced by free speech and free markets, by the politicization of science, and by current events (EPA, international agreements). The course text will be supplemented with articles from new media and from the scientific, public policy, and legal literature.
Books (for catalog) 1: Naomi Oreskes and Erik M. Conway|Merchants of Doubt: How a Handful of Scientists Obscured the Truth on Issues from Tobacco Smoke to Global Warming|Bloomsbury|2010|
Readings catalog text: Readings: Naomi Oreskes and Erik M. Conway, Merchants of Doubt: How a Handful of Scientists Obscured the Truth on Issues from Tobacco Smoke to Global Warming (Bloomsbury, 2010).
course_info_string: Estimated outside work is three hours per week. Class size is limited to 22.
other_req_materials: Additional materials will be provided on the course website by the SGL.
sgl_bio_1: Robert Schafer was an Associate Professor of City and Regional Planning at Harvard and then a practicing attorney. He has a background in science and economics.
Colloquium Room: I cannot use the Colloquium Room.

title: Joseph Conrad: Politics and the Fight for Man's Soul
course_desc: Joseph Conrad, one of the greatest writers of the 20th century, wrote two fascinating political novels, Nostromo and The Secret Agent. In Nostromo, he depicts not only the lives and fates of an array of eighteen characters, but also the physical and political composition of a mythical South American country. The Secret Agent, a tale of terrorism, is a dark satire on Edwardian society, yet strikingly contemporary. In these novels, we will examine such issues as identity, love, greed, justice, passion, and the isolation of the individual within the constraints of society.  We will also read one of Conrad’s most intriguing short stories, The Secret Sharer, which explores isolation, moral ambiguity, and self- discovery. This study group is intended for enquiring minds eager to engage in spirited dialogue.
Books (for catalog) 1: Joseph Conrad|The Secret Agent|Penguin Classics|1907|x
Books (for catalog) 2: Joseph Conrad|Nostromo|Oxford World Classics|2007|x
Books (for catalog) 3: Joseph Conrad|Typhoon and Other Tales|Oxford World Classics|2009|x
Readings catalog text: Readings: Only these editions: Joseph Conrad, The Secret Agent (Penguin Classics, 1907); Joseph Conrad, Nostromo (Oxford World Classics, 2007); Joseph Conrad, Typhoon and Other Tales (Oxford World Classics, 2009).
course_info_string: Estimated outside work is three hours per week. Class size is limited to 18.
sgl_bio_1: Mimi Hooper, a student and teacher of literature, is fascinated by works that consider the human condition and issues of identity, moral values, and the challenges facing our contemporary society. She has led many literature courses at HILR.
Colloquium Room: I cannot use the Colloquium Room.

title: Social Issues in Italian Comic and Serious Films
course_desc: From the Grand Tour to modern-day tourism, the Italy of the imagination has often been central to visitors’ views of the country. Several award-winning comedies to be viewed in class reflect attitudes that have shaped Italy. These films use piercing social farce harking back to the commedia dell’arte tradition. From the North/South divide of the haves and the have-nots to marriage, romantic love, agricultural Italy, and emigration, we will gain perspectives on the forces that drive the country. We will also view one serious film, which delineates the legacy of Italy’s 19th-century sharecropping system. How do these issues affect Italy today? What lessons about society can we learn that are still relevant? How do images influence and challenge our understandings of society? We will view the films in class and then discuss these and other questions.
course_info_string: Estimated outside work is one hour per week. Class size is limited to 22.
other_req_materials: Various articles about the films and related social issues will be posted on the course website.
other_readings: Comedies to be shown will be selected from Ciao Professore, Bread and Chocolate, Americorde and Divorce Italian Style. Tree of the Wooden Clogs is a serious film. Only three comedies will be shown if it is not possible to extend four classes by half an hour. Various articles about the films and related social issues will be posted on the website for the course.
sgl_bio_1: Carol Albright taught at Harvard Extension School. For 25 years, she was editor of the academic journal Italian Americana. She has edited three anthologies and published numerous articles about Italian topics.
Colloquium Room: I can use the Colloquium Room if that is the only way to accommodate my class size and schedule.
special_req: I'd prefer a Tues. PM or Wed. PM slot for my course. Some classes may need to begin at 12:30 to accomodate movie length.
further_info: One serious film is three hours long and will be shown and discussed over two sessions. The three comedies are shorter and the remaining four sessions should enable sufficient viewing time and discussion, especially if we can start at 12:30 for some of these. If we can start earlier, I may be able to accomodate a fourth comedy.

title: Playwrights Hansberry, Miller, and Williams: The Dream that Clings
course_desc: This course offers a close reading of three major dramatic works: Lorraine Hansberry's A Raisin in the Sun; Arthur Miller's Death of a Salesman; and Tennessee Williams' A Streetcar Named Desire. Our analysis will explore variations of “the dream,” an undercurrent in these complex, iconic plays: the dream deferred in Raisin, all the wrong dreams in Salesman, and the dream defeated in Streetcar. Further, we will examine the roots of the characters’ struggles, family tensions, and cultural tensions. Above all, we will be attentive to the individual character's quest for human dignity. Two weeks will be spent discussing each play.
Books (for catalog) 1: Lorraine Hansberry|A Raisin in the Sun|Vintage Books|1994|x
Books (for catalog) 2: Tennessee Williams|A Streetcar Named Desire|New Directions Books|2004|x
Books (for catalog) 3: Arthur Miller|Death of a Salesman|Penguin Plays|1976|x
Readings catalog text: Readings: Only these editions: Lorraine Hansberry, A Raisin in the Sun (Vintage Books, 1994); Tennessee Williams, A Streetcar Named Desire (New Directions Books, 2004); Arthur Miller, Death of a Salesman (Penguin Plays, 1976).
course_info_string: Estimated outside work is two hours per week. Class size is limited to 22.
sgl_bio_1: Linda Zeltzer taught literature and writing for 22 years at Boston College. At HILR, Linda has led 16 study groups, including courses on literature, film, and HILR study group leadership.
Additional Schedule Information: No
Colloquium Room: I cannot use the Colloquium Room.
special_req: I am not comfortable teaching in a room with a conference table.Tess has been most accommodating to my request for 1st choice room 305 or room 120 if either is available. I have been in room 305 for the last three courses I have led.

title: The Bauhaus and Harvard
course_desc: “The Bauhaus and Harvard” is a major exhibit at The Harvard Art Museums on the 100<sup>th</sup> anniversary of the founding of the Bauhaus in Weimar, Germany, in 1919. Two hundred works by 75 artists from the Busch-Reisinger Museum collection are featured. The Bauhaus, closed in 1933 by the Nazis, became the most influential school of art, architecture, and design in the world. It did away with separation of craft from fine art.  Walter Gropius, founding director of the Bauhaus who joined Harvard’s Department of Architecture in 1937, gathered artists fleeing the Nazis and assembled their works in the Busch-Reisinger Museum. Included in the exhibit are Anni and Joseph Albers, Herbert Bayer, Lyonel Feininger, and László Moholy-Nagy. We will explore and discuss these works in an interactive format.  The class will be held at the Harvard Art Museums.
Books (for catalog) 1: Magdelena Droste|Bauhaus|TASCHEN|2015|x
Readings catalog text: Readings: This edition only: Magdelena Droste, Bauhaus (TASCHEN, 2015); ,  (, ).
course_info_string: Estimated outside work is two hours per week. Class size is limited to 12.
sgl_bio_1: Betty W. Stone was a docent for 11 years at the Harvard Art Museums and a gallery instructor at the Museum of Fine Arts for eight years. She has led other courses at HILR on the Bauhaus in the Busch-Reisinger collection.
Additional Schedule Information: No.
small_room: We do not need a room.  All classes will be given at the Harvard Art Museums
further_info: The presentation will be a mix of lecture and discussion.  We will look at the art works and discuss them at length.

title: Johannes Brahms and Friends
course_desc: "Here again is one who comes as if sent from God!" Thus begins Clara Schumann's diary following the first visit of the 20-year old Johannes Brahms. Robert Schumann's entry was short, but to the point: "Visit from Brahms (a genius)." We will investigate the life of this major 19th century composer concentrating on the compositions for voice, strings, and clarinet. Through discussions of Jan Swafford's acclaimed biography and live performances by the SGL and cherished HILR surprise guests, we will become better acquainted with Brahms' harmonic and melodic genius that place him among the panoply of the great musical personalities of the time. The ability to read music is helpful, but not a requirement. Class time will be devoted to live performances, videos, and a distinguished guest lecturer.
Books (for catalog) 1: Jan Swafford|Johannes Brahms: A Biography|Vintage|1999|
Readings catalog text: Readings: Jan Swafford, Johannes Brahms: A Biography (Vintage, 1999).
course_info_string: Estimated outside work is three hours per week. Class size is limited to 25.
other_req_materials: The SGL will be sharing videos and articles with the class.
other_readings: Video performances and lectures on Brahms coupled with links to pertinent articles.
sgl_bio_1: Fredrik Wanger, pianist and teacher, is a graduate of the Oberlin and Peabody Conservatories. He has performed and recorded with many past and present principal players of the BSO and extensively with his wife, Jane. Fred has led and co-led approximately 20 study groups about music.
Additional Schedule Information: I am constricted by my own schedule and that of the performers I hope to bring to the course.  Wednesday, p.m. is truly best for me.
Colloquium Room: I strongly prefer the Colloquium Room.
special_req: Because of the extensive use of the piano, the Colloquium Room is the only option.

title: It's Time to Lead Your First Study Group!
course_desc: Have you been at HILR over two years but not yet led a study group? Well, now is the time to prepare! In this hands-on course, you will learn what makes a compelling topic. You will delve into the purpose of a syllabus and then get started on designing your course. Each member will practice leading a short discussion in our supportive class environment. We will discuss when and how to add discussions to mini-lectures on a topic. One class will cover technologies: explaining the use of Canvas to create a course website and demonstrating how to use the podium. All will be done in a collaborative, supportive, discussion-group setting with experienced SGLs and guest speakers. By the end of the class, you should feel ready to submit a course proposal and feel confident that you will have any needed help throughout your first SGL experience.
course_info_string: Estimated outside work is two hours per week. Class size is limited to 12.
other_req_materials: Articles on study group leadership will be provided on the course website.
sgl_bio_1: Judy Uhl has taught courses on technology, literature, and the impact of social media on society. Judy enjoys creating a stimulating learning environment while making the class fun. She is a member of the Teaching and Learning and the Technology committees.
sgl_bio_2: David Bliss has led HILR classes in history, science, and art. These study groups combined visual presentations with discussion.  He is a member of the Curriculum Committee.
Additional Schedule Information: Any day but Monday am.  This course worked well on Tuesday a.m. before.
small_room: Need both a podium and the computer/projector. This is critical for this class. Even if the class is small, we can't use one of the smaller rooms.
special_req: none.
further_info: Will follow much of the syllabus conceived by Ollie and Dan's version of this course. We imagine that we won't get lots of takers, but if we do, we would be amenable to figuring out how to accommodate everyone who applies. We may involve CC and TLC members in class discussions or mentoring class members on specific issues.

title: The Cambridge 5: Duplicity and Betrayal in Service of King and Country
course_desc: The Cambridge 5 spy ring was a group of upper-class English gentlemen who converted to Communism when they attended Cambridge University in the early 1930s, and then became undercover agents for the Soviet Union for the next 30 years. Great Britain was in the throes of a worldwide economic depression with massive unemployment, and Nazism under Hitler was steadily rising to power. What drove the Cambridge 5 to betray their country and class? How could they operate as agents of the Soviet Union during both World War II and the Cold War without being uncovered by the security services in which they served? This study group will use two books to examine their actions and impact; one dealing with the most prominent member of the group, Kim Philby, and the second dealing with the most destructive, Donald Maclean.
Books (for catalog) 1: Ben Macintyre|A Spy Among Friends|Crown|2014|
Books (for catalog) 2: Roland Phillips|A Spy Named Orphan|W.W. Norton & Company|2018|
Readings catalog text: Readings: Ben Macintyre, A Spy Among Friends (Crown, 2014); Roland Phillips, A Spy Named Orphan (W.W. Norton & Company, 2018).
course_info_string: Estimated outside work is three hours per week. Class size is limited to 22.
other_req_materials: SGL will provide PDF copies of Yuri Modin, My 5 Cambridge Friends: Burgess, MacLean, Philby, Blunt and Cairncross by Their KGB Controller, and other relevant materials.
sgl_bio_1: Gene Ferrari has led numerous courses over 20 years in astronomy, cosmology, earth science, and history. His courses in history have included one on Hitler and Stalin and another on the causes of World War II.
Additional Schedule Information: Please do not schedule in conflict with Murray Smith and Dan McCarthy's course on early humans which I want to take
Colloquium Room: I can use the Colloquium Room if that is the only way to accommodate my class size and schedule.
further_info: I anticipate primarily discussion in this course

title: The Modern Irish Short Story
course_desc: The short story has an important place in Irish literature, dating back to the country’s ancient oral story-telling tradition. Today’s stories by Irish writers reflect the changing social, political, and personal landscape of this small island nation that has produced a remarkable number of great writers. Many of us are familiar with the short stories of James Joyce and William Trevor, but there are many more Irish short story writers who should be read and appreciated. This study group will explore short stories from the last half of the 20th century to the present by contemporary authors, such as Mary Lavin, Dermot Bolger, Ann Enright, John McGahern, Claire Keegan, and many more. Study group members will be expected to read each story closely and to discuss, analyze, and enjoy these tales of emigration, humor, suffering, change, and loneliness. We will read two to three stories each week.
Books (for catalog) 1: Ann Enright, editor|The Granta Book of the Irish Short Story|Granta Books, General Edition|2012|
Books (for catalog) 2: Claire Keegan|Foster|Faber & Faber|2010|x
Readings catalog text: Readings: Ann Enright, editor, The Granta Book of the Irish Short Story (Granta Books, General Edition, 2012); This edition only: Claire Keegan, Foster (Faber & Faber, 2010).
course_info_string: Estimated outside work is two hours per week. Class size is limited to 12.
other_req_materials: Supplementary materials will be available through links on the course website.
other_readings: Frank O'Connor, "The Lonely Voice" (on short stories)
sgl_bio_1: Eileen Collins has visited Ireland several times and has read many novels and short stories by Irish writers.
Additional Schedule Information: I prefer afternoons because of the unreliability of morning traffic.
small_room: A smallclassroomwold be quite acceptable since there will be, I hope, plenty of discussion of these stories.
further_info: I would like some advice on choosing the number of stories each week.

title: Touching the Mind of a Suicidal Genius, Book II: Runaway Horses
course_desc: This study group will focus on Runaway Horses, the second of Mishima Yukio's cycle of four novels, known as the Sea of Fertility. Runaway Horses brings us the first reincarnation of the central character in the first book, Spring Snow; it will be important to have read Spring Snow before joining this study group. In Spring Snow, the central character dies for love; in Runaway Horses, he dies for honor. The history explored is the background for the suicidal militarization of Japan, which ultimately led to the atomic bombing of Hiroshima and Nagasaki. We all have to deal with death and loss, perhaps more immediately as we get older. Death and loss are among the central foci of Japanese culture, and death was the central focus of Mishima's life. He committed suicide in 1970, in part to announce the completion of the Sea of Fertility to the world.
Books (for catalog) 1: Yukio Mishima, trans. Michael Gallagher|Runaway Horses|Tuttle Publishing|1973|X
Readings catalog text: Readings: This edition only: Yukio Mishima, trans. Michael Gallagher, Runaway Horses (Tuttle Publishing, 1973).
course_info_string: Estimated outside work is three hours per week. Class size is limited to 12.
other_req_materials: The SGL will also post brief summaries of Japanese history and the life and career of Mishima on the website.
other_readings: There are several other Internet links, and suggested readings, including other works by Mishima, that I will point to.  None of them are required.
sgl_bio_1: Win Burr has been fascinated with Japan since college days. He spent about a year living in Japan, eight months as a visiting professor at Kyoto University.  He has led several HILR study groups on Japanese literature and looks forward to continuing with the second book of Mishima's tetralogy.
Additional Schedule Information: Monday AM
small_room: The smaller groups are much better for discussion, and I strongly suspect that interest in this group will be limited by the strong suggestion that SGMs will have read Spring Snow before joining the group.
special_req: I cannot come to HILR on Tuesdays or Wednesdays
further_info: I will start with a brief presentation of the text and issues related to the text.  Most of the time will be group discussion.

title: Location, Location, Location: A Geopolitical View
course_desc: Have you ever wondered why China is obsessed with the small country of Tibet? Why Russia and Germany have such histories of aggression? Or whether the United States was destined to become the preeminent superpower? If so, then join us as we look at major areas of the world through the lens of their geopolitical assets and constraints. This study group will explore reasons behind actions individual countries have taken in the past and discuss their most pressing current issues. We will conclude by examining current geographical realities such as climate change as well as new technologies such as fracking, nuclear icebreakers, and artificial intelligence to see how each will affect the balance of power between nations.
Books (for catalog) 1: Tim Marshall|Prisoners of Geography: Ten Maps That Explain Everything About The World|Scribner|2015|
Readings catalog text: Readings: Tim Marshall, Prisoners of Geography: Ten Maps That Explain Everything About The World (Scribner, 2015).
course_info_string: Estimated outside work is three hours per week. Class size is limited to 18.
other_req_materials: Links to scholarly journal articles, news items, and other sources will be posted on the course website.
other_readings: We will be projecting maps on the whiteboard through power point to aid in class discussions.
sgl_bio_1: Carol Reiling has been a university administrator and an entrepreneur, and most recently taught history at North Shore Community College for 15 years. She has had an abiding interest in how nations navigate the global currents to either survive, prosper, or dominate.
sgl_bio_2: Ginny Fruhan, a former lawyer, has taught history at Buckingham Browne and Nichols School and English at the Roxbury Latin School. She has long enjoyed exploring new ways of looking at the world through discussion with others.
Colloquium Room: I cannot use the Colloquium Room.
special_req: Because our course is discussion-based as well as reliant on maps projected on the whiteboard that are visible to all SGMs, we request Room 204 or 205.
further_info: After an initial discussion of  what geopolitics involves, we will be looking at different sections of the world each week: the sea powers (mainly U.S.), the land powers (Russia, Germany), and a land power becoming a sea power (China).  We then study areas of the world that have been affected by the imposition of artificial borders, namely Africa and the Middle East.  Finally, we turn our attention to two areas of particular future interest, India/Pakistan and the Arctic.  We wrap up by discussing issues that will impact geopolitics in the future:  water scarcity, climate change, the politics of energy, and the rise of artificial intelligence.  With each class, we have developed power point presentations displaying appropriate maps. In addition to readings from the texts, we will be assigning relevant articles from journals and newspapers.

title: Immigration and Integration in Israel
course_desc: Ethnicity, generational conflict, exile and the need to integrate, accommodate and remember are paramount concerns in an immigrant’s life when adjusting to a new society.  These concerns can be exacerbated for a minority culture embedded in a different majority culture.  How do these issues play out in Israel?  We will gain insight into this question by viewing and discussing three films – “Live and Become,” “Walk on Water” and “Sand Storm,” as well as discussing selected readings on the history of Israel, its current politics, and the immigration of various peoples to Israel.  Our goal will be a better understanding of the trials and tribulations of immigrants and indigenous cultures within Israel.
Readings catalog text: Readings: This edition only: Dan Senor and Saul Singer, Start Up Nation (Hachette Books Group, 2009).
course_info_string: Estimated outside work is two hours per week. Class size is limited to 22.
other_req_materials: Selected readings focused on demographics, immigration patterns, and associated debates in Israeli society will be provided on the course website.
sgl_bio_1: Barbara Resnek received a graduate degree in International Relations as well as a Law degree.  She primarily practiced family law for 20 years.  For many 20 years she has served on the Board of the Boston Jewish Film Festival and is currently the Board Chair.
Additional Schedule Information: Tuesdays and Thursday the better days for me
Colloquium Room: I strongly prefer the Colloquium Room.
special_req: The films would show best on a large screen and have been shown at movie theatres. Note that one film is slightly longer than 2 hours. It could be shown in one extended class session, or, if need be, in two segments across two classes.
further_info: Session 1 would be devoted to background on demographics and immigration laws in Israel. There are interesting articles about the varied population of Israel and demographics, which I would have participants read before the first class. Most relevant material is from the Web. There would also be some brief preparation for Live and Become. In preparation for session 2, I would ask participants to read material on Ethiopian Jews. We would watch Live and Become in that session, or perhaps split across the second and third sessions (slightly longer than 2 hours). The third session would involve discussion of the readings and film. In session 4, I would show Walk on Water, with discussion in week 5. Readings for that film related to memories of the Holocaust. In week 6, we would watch and discuss Sand Storm, with discussion continuing in week 7. Week 8 would be devoted to the integration of indigenous communities (Bedouins, Druze, Christians) into Israeli society. In week 9, we would discuss the special case of immigration from the former USSR, which will allow for contrasts to the circumstances confronting other immigrant groups. The final week would be devoted to tying together what we have learned.

I agree that the topic is appealing and could elicit a thought provoking study group. I particularly like Sand Storm as it deals with issues that are central to many Israelis today, and are widely discussed and debated within the general population.
I have a  number of questions/comments:
I believe it is important to include the laws of Israel concerning immigration: The Law of the Return and more very recent Law on the Jewish Nation. Without this legal and historical background, it is hard to understand Israel's stance on immigration. 
I am not sure how Live and Become is central to the core issues of immigration and identity within Israel. It seems to be a thoughtful film on an important topic, but not one in which immigration or identity are central.
There are films about African migrants to Israel, whose fate as aliens within the culture is quite bleak and contested. Could they be considered for such a course? Many in Israel see their situation as emblematic of the major contradictions within Israel about immigration - shunning Africans while embracing Russians, many of whom are not Jews but do bolster the white, highly educated population in Israel.
